dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last rays of sunset stream through a large stained gl window. The resonant SOUNDS of the CHOIR are infused with unmistakable gospel spirit The choir, like the CONGREGATION, is almost all black. Th hymn reaches its rousing conclusion. A distinguished look MINISTER, mid-forties, finishes his sermon.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: ... yes, we have been wounded. The forces of darkness have conspired to turn what we fought for in the '50's and '60's, justice, dignity, compassion - into the shame and poverty of the 1970's. There are some who say that we should give up hope, that we will never see the blessed community we dreamt of. But remember - you cannot wait for the Lord, you must seek him. So too you cannot wait for justice. Don't give into despair. Have the courage to seek, for in searching you will find dignity and the light of the Lord will be upon you.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: (in unison) Amen!

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: May your love of God Almighty give you peace as you leave this place and set out into the world.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: (in unison) Amen! As the CHOIR begins the exit hymn ("Marching to Zion"), t MINISTER moves down from the podium and begins to greet h parishioners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flood light illuminates the night. Reverend Lawson emer carrying his homework. He's intercepted by IONE TURNER, two hundred pounds of l She engulfs him with a hug.

dialogues.speaker: IONE
dialogues.text: Reverend, you sure did the Lord's work today, and then some! Pulling a sweet potato pie from her bag.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Sister Ione, you're too kind.

dialogues.speaker: IONE
dialogues.text: And I know you loves sweet potatoes. He sings like a bird.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: What...? Ione pulls her chunky grandson, a ten year-old version of herself, from behind her mammoth flanks.

dialogues.speaker: TONE
dialogues.text: My grandson, Willie (prodding the boy) Willie... Eye On The Sparrow...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Y'know, Brother Boxer has choir practice every...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (singing badly) I sing because I'm happy, I sing because I'm free... etc.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Oh boy, Brother Boxer's gotta hear this... He tries to extricate himself, but she snags him and pull another pie from her paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: TONE
dialogues.text: Got a peach cobbler here, too, Reverend. I was thinking maybe a solo next Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Brother Boxer has complete control of solos. But... you never know... He makes his escape, heading toward the parking lot, lade with desserts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIGURE emerges and moves in the direction of the parkin lot. Soft-soled shoes move silently across the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: ON LAWSON'S VW BUG
dialogues.text: The Minister puts his work into the car, then stops. He senses a presence. He turns around slowly, his face registers concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged WHITE WOMAN approaches. She clutches a larg handbag. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Reverend Lawson?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (tentative) Yes... The Woman reaches into her purse, fumbles for something. gun? No. She finally pulls out a SMALL FOLDER.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE WOMAN
dialogues.text: I found her. They had her under a different name. It was like she didn't exist. She offers the file to Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor is crowded. The door to the men's room swing open. A handsome gentleman exits. The man is HIRAM EVANS, elegantly dressed, late fifties, a prominent African-Amer lawyer in Memphis. Evans heads toward Courtroom 4.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hiram! Evans turns to see Lawson emerge from the crowd. These tw are old friends. Evans is still moving toward the courtro Lawson follows.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: God-damn brother Lawson, you still growing or am I shrinking?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (grinning) New boots. It's the heels. And if you keep taking the Lord's name in vain, I'm gonna put you on the Raffle Committee with Sister Ione.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Cruel and unusual punishment...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Hiram, I need your help... sticks his head out of courtroom 4.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Everybody for Judge Harper's courtroom, we're back in session.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Gotta go. Harper is about to rule in my favor. He's tough as a two dollar steak - don't want to keep him waitin'.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Hiram... We've found Grace!

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: (chuckles) I should hope so, Reverend!

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Grace Walden. She's been locked up in the State Asylum for almost a decade. I need you to get her out.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Brother, times have changed. We ain't marching any more.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Hiram, she's the key. We gotta get her out.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: If you can't let this go, then what you need is one of them. (he indicates the white faces in court) You and I together wouldn't get past the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the sharpest lawyer I know.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Flattery ain't gonna do it, Jim. There are times when a white face is the right face. Gotta go. (a smile) And Jim ... we don't need any more martyrs. Watch your back, brother. Evans turns abruptly and heads back into the courtroom. Lawson stands alone. This isn't the first time he has bee rebuffed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE eyes Hiram as he returns, sitting next to his wealthy white client.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Nice of you to rejoin us, Mr. Evans. LAWSON enters the courtroom, and sits towards the back.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: The matter is clear as a screen door, your honor, The Tennessee code annotated is explicit as to the points we've presented. We therefore rest on the briefs submitted and ask for a directed verdict.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Morgan? The Judge looks at CLAY MORGAN JR. Morgan is a corporate lawyer in his late thirties who talks Southern, dresses London, and charms all the time. Morgan gets up from behi the defense table. He knows that he's holding a busted straight but still is compelled to strut

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, you're Honor. I realize my esteemed colleague has presented a compelling case... BOOM. Morgan turns to the origin of the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rear doors to the courtroom SLAM shut. Enter JEFFREY JENKINS, walking quickly, holding a large legal volume.  6. Jeff's hair is a little too long and his clothes reflect indifference to appearance or trends. Jeff walks up to th defense table and sets the book down.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (to Morgan, sotto voce) I've got to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me your honor. (irritated) What? Morgan walks back to the defense table. Jeff slides the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to him.

dialogues.speaker: ON LAWSON
dialogues.text: : (MORE ) cea . From Lawson's distant POV, Morgan appears to be assisting awkward junior associate.

dialogues.speaker: ON MORGAN AND JEFF
dialogues.text: Morgan's expression changes from irritated to inspired.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Your Honor, Please excuse my young associate. As I was saying, our research shows that the question of jurisdiction enjoys precedence. (picks up the book) Title 28, Section 1441[a] and Rule 81[c] of the federal rules of...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Morgan, maybe y'all haven't noticed, but we are ina state court. The Federal Court is down the block. LAUGHTER from the room. Lawson watches, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Good point, Your Honor. And that's where this whole shebang oughta' be. According to Title 28, we do not require an order of this court to remove this case to the United States District Court. That court is, as you noted, just down the block. (to Jeff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, why don't you pass that Federal Rules book to Judge Harper. Jeff hands the book to the Bailiff who passes it to the Judge. The Judge quickly reads the passage to himself.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Evans, this court no longer has jurisdiction. Next case. Lawson takes notice. Evans' confident demeanor has given to resignation. Evans walks over to Morgan who is just standing. Evans offers his hand in congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Good job, Clay. You could steal the flowers off a dead man's grave. See you in Federal Court.

dialogues.speaker: MA
dialogues.text: Ready when you are, counselor Jeff watches Morgan bask in victory. As Hiram turns to le he notices Lawson approaching the defense table. Hiram wi at Lawson, then exits. Lawson holds out his hand to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mr. Morgan. Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You have a gift. Be nice to see that gift working to help the less fortunate. Morgan puts his files in his briefcase. Snaps it shut, looking for a graceful exit.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: It does, I assure you. But right now I'm so busy I should be twins.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I could use your help. A civil matter. A woman, wrongfully incarcerated...

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: (to Jeff) Give the Reverend my business card. (to Lawson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already late. Why don't you call me at the office. Morgan picks up his case and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classy surroundings. Georgian furniture and wood paneling Start CLOSE on the receptionist, CYBIL STURGIS, 50-someth and very prim. She's plugged into a hands-free PBX.

dialogues.speaker: CYBIL
dialogues.text: Good morning. Branson, Davis and Douglas. One moment please. I'll transfer you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miss... REVEAL Jim Lawson. He's been waiting patiently for some time. He gets up from the stiff couch and approaches the receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...Do you think you could try Mr. Morgan again?

dialogues.speaker: CYBIL
dialogues.text: Sir, I've told you. Mr. Morgan is in conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toy basketball arches through a small hoop.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing but net! Pull back to reveal the plush office, the carefully appoi space that befits a junior partner of a prestigious white shoe firm. Morgan sits at his desk, playing toy basketbal with CHUCK ARMSTRONG (39), another rising legal star.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) The crowd goes wild. That's another Jackson, pal. Armstrong hands twenty dollars to Morgan. There is a KNOC at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Come in. Jeff enters carrying a sizeable legal brief.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I've finished the response to the Conway case. (to Armstrong) Morning Chuck. Armstrong just nods. Morgan reaches for the brief.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: You've finished the first draft of the response.

dialogues.speaker: CYBIL, (V.0)
dialogues.text: (on the intercom) Mr. Morgan, I just want to remind you that Reverend Lawson is still waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Cybil, I'm busy. Tell him to leave the file. I'll get back to him. Please.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wrongful incarceration. It sounds pretty straightforward. Morgan is surprised that Jeff even knows about the case, alone has an opinion.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Nothing's straightforward in the law, Jeffrey. Didn't your distinguished daddy tell you that? If the state took the time to put some old black lady in the basket factory, there must be a damn good reason.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Maybe just look through the file...

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: It's pro bono, kid. Gotta bill the hours or hit the showers. Branson will never go for it. But hell, go ahead. Present it at the Partners' meeting. It's all yours.  10. Morgan retrieves another toy ball and shoots.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) He shoots, he scores!

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You are to be commended. Billing for the quarter is outpacing the same quarter '75 by ten percent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on WILLIAM 'BILL' BRANSON, a southern gentleman wit shark's toothy smile. Senior and Junior partners are seat at the table, while Associates sit behind them along the wall. Jeff is seated on the outer perimeter, next to KATY BOLTON, an attractive, poised, twenty-six year old, and t only black face in the room. Katy is taking notes ona yellow pad.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Let's keep the billing hours up. (a beat) If there's nothing else, I'd like to adjourn. ANGLE the room as Jeff slowly stands.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh... Mr. Branson... I gave your secretary a file on Grace Walden. She was not represented by an attorney or examined by a psychiatrist. I was wondering if you had a chance to look at it.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Yes, Jeffrey, I read it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh... According to my preliminary research, there was no apparent reason why she was placed in that institution and is still there eight years later.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: We're not talking fee here, are we?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I believe she is indigent. We were contacted by her Minister.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Where do we draw the line, Jeff? We're in the business of billable hours. We're not storefront lawyers. A painful pause. To everyone's surprise, Katy speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: A case like this could land us an article in The Memphis Lawyer, sir It could actually bring in more business. The Reverend is quite well known.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (grateful) Yes... yes. It's James Lawson. He's a friend of my father's.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: In that event, maybe I should take a look.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: If I recall correctly, Clay, your billing rate is somewhat higher than Jeff's. (to Morgan) This firm can afford ten hours for better relations with the Negro community. (to Katy) You'll keep the editors of The Memphis Lawyer informed of our commitment, and due to the nature of the case, maybe you should assist Jeff on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sidles up to Katy as the other lawyers exit and disp

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (on the move) Thanks... Branson can be a little unreceptive at times.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: It's a good case. It's the kind of thing we should do more of. We already have enough meters running in this building.  12. Clay moves past on his way to his office.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Listen... Katy... I was thinking, since we're working together, we could stop by Bolivar State Hospital on Saturday and see Miz Walden. Clay looks on, amused by Jeff's apparent awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) Then, if it's okay with you, we could swing by and enjoy some of my Dad's stringy barbecue. He's cooking. It's kinda informal.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Go to your father's for dinner? Clay has paused in his doorway to watch, grins.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: He shoots. He scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim lighting, high ceilings, peeling paint, stone floors narrow wooden benches - spare forms and haunting shadows abound. Silence and echoes including JEFF'S OWN FOOTSTEPS striking the stone, as he walks, now tentatively, into

dialogues.speaker: THE LOBBY
dialogues.text: JEFF stops and becomes aware of another SOUND: the CLICKI WOODEN TOY in the hands of a solitary inmate seated on a The inmate is BRIAN GREENE, between 40 and 60, dressed in institutional cotton bathrobe. His eyes are unfocused. Jeff continues on to the empty Reception Window and Information Desk. His mood is darkening, his breathing reacting to the heavy antiseptic smell of the place. CLOSE-UP on an old yellowing index card taped to the wind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff studies the note... Then reaches through an opening the glass partition, picks up a Visitor's Pass, and puts on his lapel. He turns and approaches the inmate on the bench, and offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hello. I'm an attorney. Jeffrey Jenkins. I came to see Grace Walden. The SOUND of the wooden TOY stops.

dialogues.speaker: GREENE
dialogues.text: Esquire. Jeffrey Jenkins, Esquire. I'm Brian Greene. Green like the color green. But there's an extra "e", It's at the end. I'm English. So it's not like the color green.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Greene, do you know Grace Walden?

dialogues.speaker: GREENE
dialogues.text: Walden. And that's spelled "e" "n" not "o" "nh"

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You know where I can find her?

dialogues.speaker: GREENE
dialogues.text: "Oo" "hn" 4s Swedish -- "e" "n" is Danish... She's in 14. Right down that hall and to the right. "0" "n" is also your Norwegian --

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Greene. Jeff walks down the hall, turns right and comes to a door

dialogues.speaker: WARD 3
dialogues.text: Jeff checks his stolen permit and continues into the ward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE WALDEN is seated on the bed, dressed in a robe, paj and slippers. She is white. Grace is fifty-five but looks at least twenty years older. She has no teeth, wears no makeup, and her sparse hair is white and wispy. She has t vacant look caused by heavy medication.  14.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (expecting a black woman) Oh, excuse me ma'am. I was looking for a Mrs. Grace Walden. I was told she was in Room 14, but...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Can't be sure anymore. What with all that's been happening...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Do you know Grace Walden?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: That's me. For all the good it's done. Grace looks up, gives a toothless smile. Jeff reacts. Awkwardly, he pulls out a business card and hands it to h

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I am Jeffrey D. Jenkins with the firm of Branson, Davis and Douglas. (Grace just stares) Reverend Lawson asked me to come see you... You know Reverend James Lawson? She shakes her head no; her eyes unfocused.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) I understand that you have been put here without benefit of counsel...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ain't no benefits in this place. You got that right. Silence. A WILD LAUGH cackles from a far ward. Jeff takes out a small tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I use a tape recorder? It'll save me taking notes. (she nods, he starts the recorder) Why did you get put in here? Can you remember?  15.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Can you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Cause Charlie told them. Not me. I wouldn't lie.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Charlie? Who's Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Threw him outa Jim's. He's in the Hornet's Nest now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two guards, EARL AND TRENT, are walking. They wear non- specific police uniforms. Earl is bald. Trent is fat. The hear VOICES down the hall, react. They move toward Room 1

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When did you last see Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I called him once. Can't call him no more... The door to the room is pushed open and the Guards enter. Earl sees the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: She's not supposed t'have any visitors. Where'd you get that pass.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm her attorney.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: She doesn't have an attorney.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She does if she says she does.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: She sure does, if she says she does. Jeff looks at Grace.  16.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: The Director is goin' to want t'see you. Bring the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'll see you later, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: We'll see. The two Guards follow Jeff out of the ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the Guards brace Jeff and rip his tape recorder away .

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (gesturing to Jeff) This way to the Director's office.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Right behind you. Jeff pretends a meek compliance, then, with a fast pivot, grabs back the recorder, leaps clear of the Guards and ru Jeff sprints full speed down the corridor, past Brian Gre and toward the main doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucolic. Birds CHIRPING. Jeff's yellow TR3 is parked not far from the main building. Katy sits in the driver's sea a legal brief is propped against the steering wheel. She carefully revising the document

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (shouting to Katy) Start the car! Start the car Katy looks up. Jeff has just run out of the main entrance He leaps down a set of stairs and rushes toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Jeff, what...? Earl and Trent in pursuit. Jeff yanks open the door

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Go, Katy. Just go! Go! Katy puts the car in gear but the Guards race to ten feet front of the car. They throw their hands up in a "stop" s  17.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drive. Step on it. They'll move.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: ‘Cause they're not crazy. Go! Katy floors it. The Guards dive away at the last instant. Katy races toward the highway.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: What's goingmoRE?! As Katy drives onto the highway, Jeff removes the tape fr the recorder and hides it in her purse. He takes a blank tape from the glove compartment and puts it into the recorder. He puts the recorder on the dash in plain sight SIREN announces the Guards' pursuit. Katy sees the POLICE in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (continuing) What the hell'd you do back there?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I interviewed my client! Pull over. The car pulls over. The Guards approach, guns drawn.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Out of the car, both of you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But can I ask one question first, Officer? Do you work for the state police?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: "Special Officer."

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What does that mean, "Special Officer"? You sure it doesn't mean "Hospital Security"? (Trent hesitates)  18.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Cause if it does, I believe your jurisdiction extends just as far as the hospital grounds -- and no farther -- right? Trust me on this. If you pull us out of this car, it's technically a kidnapping ‘cause you got zero authority here on this highway. Katy looks with admiration. She sees a new Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now unless you want her to drive right over those shiny brogans, I suggest you step back, officer ‘cause we're going now. The Guards step back slowly in apparent defeat. But then, Earl suddenly reaches into the car and grabs the tape recorder off the dash. Jeff stares as the two Guards hurry away, get into their vehicle and drive off. Now the highway is empty. Katy reaches into her purse and withdraws the tape.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: What the hell is on this thing?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don't know... gibberish. (off Katy's look) But who the hell is Grace Walden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angular MAN is backlit against a window with venetian blinds. We HEAR a door open and an AGENT enters INTO FRAM Drops a file on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Sir, the incident at Bolivar. We traced the young man. A lawyer. Working for James Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: BACKLIT MAN
dialogues.text: (a long pause) That's unfortunate. Maybe the old Reverend needs a reminder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quintessentially Southern. Neatly landscaped and beautifu lit, it leans magnificently against a moonlit sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on a fire. PULL BACK to reveal LUCAS JENKINS presid over the enormous brick barbeque. Lucas is 60, distinguished. Katy and Jeff stand close by. HAROLD, a black butler with alert eyes, wearing a white coat, hover

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Hope these sirloins aren't too thin. Harold picked 'em up at the Piggly Wiggly.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. It was all they had. Harold's eyes connect with Katy's. He holds out a platter Lucas removes the three steaks from the grill.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I wasn't making a criticism, Harold. You pick 'em and I cook ‘em. It's a Wednesday night tradition. Let's see if we can cut these without a chainsaw. Harold moves off to set the nearby table. Katy stands ina white dress. She looks ravishing. Jeff is in a blazer

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (continuing) So, Miss Bolton, Jeff tells me your father is in transportation.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (a glance at Jeff) After a fashion, I guess. He, uh drives a City bus.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: A bus. Jeff tells me you're taking the bar exam next month.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Did Jeff tell you - Branson gave him his first solo client.  20.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (to Jeff) A courtroom situation?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just a motion to install due process.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Did Bill Branson reset your hourly rate for a solo court appearance?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It's pro-bono. Your friend, Reverend Lawson, brought the case to us. Lucas wrinkles his brow slightly, then motions to the tab

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Why don't we get started? (they walk to the table) What's the client's name?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Grace Walden. Harold is pouring the wine. He hears the name, looks up momentarily, catching Lucas' eye. Everyone sits, an appetizer at each place. Katy glances down, puzzled, at h place setting. There are four forks. She doesn't know whi to use.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (stalling) Looks wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh, my, that fork looks tarnished. Harold, the master of subtlety, picks up the correct fork polishes it and hands it back to Katy.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (grateful) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Have you met your client yet?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sure did.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: And she seems sane?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: To be honest, Dad, she seemed a little disoriented...

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Maybe she's where she belongs.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She was denied due process. And before I could finish my interview, two guards ran me off. Confiscated my tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: That's strange. Whatever it is, I'm sure you'll do the right thing. Remember, it's just one case.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: My first case.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: The first of many. Lucas cuts the steak. MOVE IN ON the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ornate grandfather clock CHIMES. Lucas and Katy walk through the foyer. Jeff is absent for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: The night's young, but old men retire early. It was a pleasure meeting you, Katy.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. They walk to the front door and out onto the veranda.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: When I look at you, I seea fighter. Maybe you could teach some of that to my son.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Jeff and Harold are exiting the library. Jeff is putting his jacket. Harold holds Katy's coat.  22.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Mighty fine young lady, Mr. Jeff. Smart as a whip and pretty enough to make a man plow through a stump.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sure is, Papa H... but, we're just working together.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Hmm...Well, now that they adjusted your hourly rate, you ever need to unwind, lose some of that new money, I'm still at The Rack and Cue every Tuesday. The walk out the door onto the veranda.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas and Lawson walk down the dark church corridor. The lights are off. Lucas is fuming. Lawson has a flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Lucas, calm down. And watch your language. (calls out) Clarence, call the power company again. I need these lights back on.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: You're crazier than she is. A Choir is rehearsing in an adjacent area by candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (continuing) . Why didn't you come to me first?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I did. Eight years ago. And you didn't want to hear about it!

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I wasn't alone. Every reputable lawyer in town turned you down. So, now you've gone to my son. Behind my back! You know this could destroy him.  23.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I didn't want him to go up to Bolivar. I just wanted him to file the writ... Grace has been locked away for almost a decade...

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: James, you don't give a damn about that crazy old white woman! You just want to reopen the case.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Those efforts aren't mutually exclusive!

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: So you came to my son, to my only son... Lawson looks at his old friend.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: He wasn't my first choice, Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: You can't do this. After all we've meant to one another... all we've been through. Promise me you'll get another lawyer. Promise me, Jim. I need your word. Lawson hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest home. A LOUD KNOCK. The SOUND of youthful footsteps approaching. Lawson's nine-year-old son, SETH, complete with a Jackson Five Afro, is about to open it, when DOROTHY LAWSON (30s) strides into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Seth, I told you before... Don't open the door to strangers. She moves her son back with her hand. She looks through t fish eye in the door.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's Jeffrey Jenkins, Mrs. Lawson. I'm here to see Jim. Dorothy opens the door

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Jeffrey Jenkins. Last time I saw you, I think you were still in short pants.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I still wear ‘em, but now it's just to play ball.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Good, someone needs to put the Reverend in his place. He's out back, shooting hoops. Jeff enters the home and Dorothy begins leading him throu the neat interior. Seth runs ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sorry about the door... It's just... you can't be too careful. There've been some threatening phone calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A basketball arcs through the sky. WOOSH. Nothing but net The shooter moves in to retrieve the ball - it's Jim Laws dressed in a damp shirt, jeans and tennis shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gimme the ball, Dad! The back door flies open. Seth comes running out of the house. Jim looks up to see his son - followed by Jeff and Dorothy. Jim hesitates, bounces the ball.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Seth, take the ball inside. (tosses it to him) You've got to practice the piano. And I need to be alone with Mr. Jenkins.  25. Jeff walks toward Jim. Seth takes the ball into the house Dorothy follows her son, closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I went to Bolivar.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: That's more than I asked for.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I wanted to see for myself. I made a tape recording...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You did what?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Grace kinda rambled. But something strange is going on. A weary Jim moves to a picnic bench, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. (Jeff looks confused) I've contacted another attorney to take the case. I'm sorry. I'll see that your law firm gets paid for your time.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Is this because I never tried a case before?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: It's because of a lot of things. I made a mistake. I'd need you to return that tape.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But I can do this.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You've done enough. Just return the tape. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radio somewhere is BLARING out a disco beat. Katy is waiting with several files.  26. PULL BACK to see out the glassed front door. Jeff pulls u in his TR3, gets out, comes up the walk. Katy turns as he enters.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: I brought the stuff you wanted. But do you mind telling me what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'm sorry. It's all coming unwound.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: What's coming unwound?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Come on up. I need a beer. And you deserve an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (unsure) You think I should?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Come on. You won't believe what just happened. They MOVE OUT OF SHOT and head upstairs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Katy walk up the stairs. He moves along to his door, takes out his key.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: . When Lawson found out I went to see Grace, he got really pissed. Across the hall, a neighbor is peeking through a chain lo door. Katy turns and catches her disapproving look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katy and Jeff enter. The interior is dark. Jeff flips on the light switch and nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: These are out. A lamp comes at camera.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: The lamp smashes into Jeff and a man shoves him.  27. Jeff falls into Katy and they both go down. The man bolts of the room and into the hall. Before Katy can react, Jeff gives chase out into the dark hallway, running down the stairs, taking them three and f at a time, tripping, falling, rolling, coming to his feet the entry and out the front door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff runs out into the street just as a gray sedan takes heading right at him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF AND SEDAN
dialogues.text: Jeff dives up onto the sidewalk to avoid being hit. The sedan roars away, up the street

dialogues.speaker: LICENSE PLATE HOLDER
dialogues.text: It is empty - no plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff comes into the apartment. He has a cut over his eye where the lamp hit him. The lights are now on. The place has been thoroughly ransacked.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Gone... he got away. You got the lights back on...

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: He only unscrewed the bulbs. (she sees his cut) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. She hands a tissue to Jeff who moves to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing; dials 0) Operator, connect me with the police.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. She depresses the phone button. Jeff is confused.  28.

dialogues.speaker: KATY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look at this place. Tv's still here... stereo... She moves to a ransacked dresser.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Gold cufflinks, watch... (holds them up) Not much of a burglar.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Where's the tape?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: With the rest of the case material - - at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON a tape player.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Can you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Cause Charlie told them. Not me. I wouldn't lie. Katy and Jeff are listening, exchanging glances.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Charlie? Who's Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Threw him outa Jim's. He's in the Hornet's Nest now. Jeff reaches out and shuts off the tape.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who's Charlie? And what did he tell them?  29.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: And what's the Hornet's Nest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on an old neon sign that depicts a wasp. The Hornet Nest is a grimy bar located by the river. PULL BACK to sh Jeff looking at the sign. He moves inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a few listless drunks leaning at the bar. Jeff moves to the BARTENDER, (60, decrepit)

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Charlie who?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Old Charlie. Hangs out here.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Two of whatever Charlie drinks. The bartender pulls two long necks from the cooler. Jeff drops a twenty on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hey, C.Q. An old drunk looks up from a booth in the back.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Thanks. Jeff takes the two bottles, moves to the booth and slides

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mr. Stephens?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I ain't looking for no new friend, so git.  30. Jeff sets a beer in front of Charlie

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Strike that. Glad ta' meetcha'. Charlie Q. Stephens is not falling down drunk, but, on the other han he's never sober. Jeff hands Charlie a business card. In the dim light, Charlie tries to read it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Attorney In Law.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: At Law. I represent Grace Walden.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (bursts out laughing) Grace is a ghost, ain't you heard? They locked her up, man, threw ‘way the key. She called a couple years back. But the line went dead.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She's in trouble, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why? She din't sign no affidavit. They don't owe her no money.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why'd they lock her up?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Cause she wouldn't listen to me. I told her to sign that stupid paper. Hell, she's the one what saw him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Saw whom?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Man, you don't know shit. (he stares) She saw the guy they say shot Martin Luther King. Jeff sits there stunned.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.  31.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Take the wax outta' yer ears, kid. They say she saw King's killer. They showed her a picture. She told 'em it weren't the man she saw. Then zap! 0O1' Gracie is gone faster'n Jack's cat.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What did you see?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hell, I din't see shit. But I told hem what they wanted. Signed a paper and everything. ct

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who told you to sign a paper?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The FBI. They was nice, at first. Offered me a reward. One hundred housand crisp US dollars. After I signed, the shitheads never paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ct

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But you didn't see anything. Charlie erases this irrelevant observation with his hand the air.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They didn't say nothin' about paying me for what I saw. They said they'd pay me for what I signed! Jeff studies Charlie Q. Stephens, sure now that whatever may have happened, Charlie is telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Is there anything you know that could help get Grace out of Bolivar? There's no money in it. Charlie winces.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I could swear that Grace was never crazy... But I reckon you wouldn't want me for no witness, would you?  32. Jeff is moved by the human being, Charlie Stephens, peeri out from the "character" of the notorious loser.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have you seen her? How's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Not real good. When I met her she seemed awful confused.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sounded fine when I talked ta her on the phone. ‘Course that was some time ago.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What time a day was it? (Charlie looks confused) When she called? What time of day was it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mornin. Had to be 'fore 7. Why? What you thinkin'?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just wondering what time of day they hand out the meds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson is at his desk, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (into receiver) Look... I need the power back on. I have an evening choir service. Can't we get somebody to take a look at it? PUSH PAST his shoulder to the WINDOW. A gray TERMITE INSPECTION TRUCK is parked across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two AGENTS are monitoring the phone tap on Reverend Lawso

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) We'll try and get a crew out there ina little bit.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the button to disconnect. After he does, he he two more CLICKS. He looks at the phone, then notices the outside the window. He flips open his Rolodex, and dials.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Hello, Sister Ione? It's Reverend Lawson...

dialogues.speaker: SISTER IONE'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gospel music PLAYS. There is a picture of a White Jesus o the wall. Ione holds the phone, elated.

dialogues.speaker: TONE
dialogues.text: Oh, Reverend? Must be my lucky day.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Well, Sister Ione, luck ain't nothing but preparation meeting opportunity. Now, before Willy gets the opportunity to sing for Brother Boxer, we gotta be sure he's prepared. Is he around?

dialogues.speaker: TONE
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Willeee!!!

dialogues.speaker: INT. VAN
dialogues.text: The men with the headphones wince.

dialogues.speaker: AS NECESSARY
dialogues.text: Willie comes to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes sir...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Willy, I want you to practice for me right here, on the phone. Eye On The Sparrow.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes sir! He clears his throat, starts singing badly.  34.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing) I sing because I'm happy, I sing because I'm free...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Louder, Willy, louder. Take me home, son!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Willy belts out the song louder and way off key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy's grating singing fills the enclosure as the two Ag suffer. Tape wheels spin, recording it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a wall clock. It reads 6:30. PAN DOWN TO Brian Greene, with an "e". GUARD #3 is trying to guide Greene o of the hallway, back into his room.

dialogues.speaker: GREENE
dialogues.text: I believe it was a Rottweiler -- "en "gn "jy" -- that's a German dog! It was wandering in the hallway...

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Mr. Greene, get back to your room. JEFF, in a well-soiled food service uniform, pushes a car down the hall. A hair net and dark glasses complete his disguise. As the attendant leads Greene back to his room, Greene stops. He stares at Jeff. Then it hits him.

dialogues.speaker: GREENE
dialogues.text: Jeffrey Jenkins, Esquire! Jeffrey with a J not a G. Esquire, not like a knight, but a barrister... Jeff tries to contain his panic. The Guard looks at the grimy food service uniform, then back at Greene.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Get your ass in your room! The Guard leads Greene off. Jeff breathes deeply, moves o  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff slips into Grace's cubicle. Grace looks up and stare Jeff removes his glasses, starts talking quickly.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mrs. Walden -- it's me. Your lawyer. Jeffrey Jenkins? She looks back at him. Grace is surprised. Jeff removes t tape recorder from his pants.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) The firm of Branson, Davis and Douglas. Don't you remember? Grace stares. Jeff suddenly remembers. He removes the hai net. Grace smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Mr. Jenkins?... They sure ran you out of here the other day -- I remember that.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mrs. Walden, why are you here? (no response) We don't have much time.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you really my lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yes, Ms. Walden. This is just a disguise...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you goin' to get me out of here? I need your word.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'll do everything in my power...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No! No excuses. Last time I told what happened, it landed me in here. I need you to promise. Jeff pauses. This old woman has clearly been through hell  36.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You have my word, Grace. I promise. I'll get you out She studies Jeff's eyes. Hesitates, then

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: After the gun shot. I saw the man who ran down the corridor. And I wouldn't lie about it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What happened? Grace looks away; her voice and eyes remember.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I was living with Charlie Q. Stephens back then... It was April 4th of '68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace sits reading in her room. The door to her room is o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Q. Stephens, drunk and disorderly, is pounding on door of the bathroom which is shared by the entire floor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey, did you move in there? There are other people out here, you know. Will you get out of that g'damn bathroom? There is no answer. Charlie kicks the door, then turns to walk down the hallway. He passes the room he shares with Grace, then starts to descend the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie leaves the building and heads for the alley besid the house, complaining.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch thinks he owns the bathroom... Charlie begins to urinate, still mumbling and complaining  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace remains in her room, reading her book. As she rocks her rocking chair, an EXPLOSION from a high-powered rifle rattles the room! Grace bolts up. She hears FOOTSTEPS. Grace turns towards the hallway. Her door is partially op

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN -- short, approximately 50 years old, rushes past Grace's door. He is carrying something in his right hand. His body intervenes between the object and Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start TIGHT ON Grace.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Five minutes later, seemed like there were police everywhere. They brought in some guy who wanted me to help put together a picture of the man I saw...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: An identikit?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Something like that... And after I finished with that artist, the FBI came. I told them everything I knew and they left...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But they came back that summer in early June... TwO FBI AGENTS have photos and documents spread out befor Grace. Charlie Stephens sits in a corner watching and listening. One agent is PAUL and the other is BOBBY LEE.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY LEE
dialogues.text: . Alright, now, honey, sign right here.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I don't have my glasses.  38.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's an affidavit. It says that this man -- (flashes photo) -- James Earl Ray, is the man you saw on the day of the murder.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You already know who he is?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They got him over in England. And when you sign this, they'll ship him back to us. You'll be famous. It's for your country. Charlie's big eyes are looking for an opening. Grace sees Charlie signaling her.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY LEE
dialogues.text: Then there's the money. Some people here in Memphis have offered a reward of $100,000. Wouldn't you like to have $100,000?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: That would be very nice. The FBI Agents share a look.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You bet. So just put your John Hancock right here.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (finds her glasses) Could you show me that picture again? Bobby Lee pushes a photo over to her. Grace studies the picture.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You got the wrong man.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (impatient) Let me assure you, Mrs. Walden, we have the right man.  39.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The man I saw come past that door was older, shorter, and thinner than this man. Didn't look anything like him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY LEE
dialogues.text: Don't you want to help your country?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I sure do. You find the right man and I'll sign that affidavit. Gotta say what I truly seen. Bobby Lee knows he's got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You never signed the affidavit?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I couldn't. They had the wrong man.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I wish I wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK SCREEN. Suddenly, a hole gets kicked into the mid of the shot as TWO MEN, back lit, throw open the door and rush into the room.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (V.0)
dialogues.text: But I wouldn't lie. So they came back... middle of the night. They break into our room. The two men drag a half awake Grace out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Whatcha doing? Stop it! Leggo' a me!  40. One of the men has restraints in his jacket. Grace is bou and pulled out of the rooming house.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Next thing I know, I'm in here. Won't let me talk to anyone on the outside. I'm the only one. No visits. Not even by telephone. And that's over eight years now. Jeff just stares with a growing concern. He shuts off the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm going to get you out of here, Grace. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Backlit Man is on the phone. Grainy black and white surveillance photos of Jeff and Lawson are on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BACKLIT MAN
dialogues.text: These guys aren't getting the message. (listens) It's worth a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson is preaching without a mike.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: We're having our service today without electricity, but Jesus didn't need electricity.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: They can kill the power, but they can't kill our power, because our power's from above and we sure pay that monthly bill right here, don't we?  41.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Amen. The door at the side of the rostrum opens and two men in suits walk toward the lectern. The congregation gets quie Lawson does not see the men at first, but he is struck by quiet congregation. He turns to see the first suit withdr a wallet from his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Reverend. We're from the IRS.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I'm conducting a church service.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: And we're conducting a tax audit. (hands over an envelope) Could you please have your '73 through '75 records at our office tomorrow. By ten A.M. Sorry for the inconvenience. They turn and leave as Lawson looks after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STRING QUARTET is playing a medley from Show Boat, risi to "Old Man River." Lucas is at a table reading the Press Scimatar. Jeff approaches. He's edgy, slightly disheveled

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. (he sits) Everything's just turned upside down. First Lawson puts me on the Walden case, then he tries to pull me off. I meet Grace. She seems crazy one day, then clear-as-a- bell the next. Then I find Grace's companion, guy named Charlie Q. Stephens...

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Charlie Q. Stephens?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Of him. Scrambled eggs!  A passing WAITER leans in.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: For dinner, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (laughing) No. Just bring us some champagne. (to Jeff) What do you want with Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He's a key witness in the Walden case...

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: .. Charlie Stephens didn't witness dogshit!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How do you know Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: He was a big deal for fifteen minutes. Said he saw James Earl Ray run out of the rooming house after Dr. King was shot. Hell, he just wanted the reward money we offered. The Waiter brings and pours the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: "Wwe"?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I was part of a local committee. Set up a reward fund to solve the murder. (gestures Waiter over) Henri, how's the Sole tonight?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Very fresh.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (to Jeff) For both of us? (Jeff nods) And some gumbo to start. The waiter leaves. 42.  43.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why didn't Charlie ever get his reward money?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Because he never testified. He didn't have to! James Earl Ray pled guilty. Had no choice. They found the murder weapon with his prints all over it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And Grace? She's still out at Bolivar.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: That may have been an injustice. But her incarceration is not evidence of some conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Look, dad, I'm not a conspiracy nut. I'm just a lawyer trying to win my first case.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: You have to consider more than winning, son. You have to consider what's best for your client. Can she take care of herself?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. But I am sure she can't stay out there at Bolivar.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: What if you had her moved to a half- way house.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Forget the trial, no trial. Justa simple motion for relief.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She was illegally incarcerated. She deserves her day in court.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Look, if you mention the King assassination, they'll have her certified... and the only way she'll leave that place is in an urn. Listen to me: get your motion technically perfect, keep it de minimus. She'll go to a nice place, be well cared for. The waiter approaches, sets down two bowls of soup.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Enjoy your soup. Jeff is pensive. Lucas looks at him, then picks up his sp and samples the gumbo. It's terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large and spacious, there is an Oriental rug over hardwoo floors and a massive conference table. Law books surround walls. Jeff is looking something up. Clay Morgan enters.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff. What makes no money, pisses off partners and sinks faster than lead shot?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Clay, I don't need this right now.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: BIZZZ! Time's up. It's your Grace Walden case. The door to the library opens and Branson enters. He noti Jeff and Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Clay could you excuse us for a moment? Clay leaves, closing the door behind him. Branson looks a Jeff, then spins his case file around and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Habeas corpus application for release? You're determined to make an opera of this, aren't you?  45.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, sir. Just defending my client.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Ten hours, that was the deal. You're way over.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, sir it's gotten kinda complicated. I believe if you... Jeff stops because Branson is glaring at him. Branson sig

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Okay, here's how it will be handled. You will appear before Judge Horace Jackson. You will file a motion for confinement to a halfway house. There will be no further suits, actions or claims. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Very clear, sir. Branson turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Katy enter the courtroom. Katy takes a seat in t first row of the spectator section, directly behind the defense table.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jeff. Jeff turns to see Lawson get up from the opposite side of courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is a mistake. Get a postponement, do what ever...

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: All rise! Court is in session. The Honorable Judge Horace Jackson presiding. Jackson enters, takes his seat. Jeff moves to his appoint spot at the defense table. A side door opens. Grace appea in the doorway, escorted by a MATRON and a GUARD.  46. She is dressed in a horrible print smock. Her hair is a m and she isn't wearing her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (turns to Katy) Where's her new dress?

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I delivered it myself. Grace is led to the defense table.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Grace? Are you alright. Where's the dress we bought you? Grace stares off in the distance, drugged.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing; to the Matron) Come on, lady, what'd you give her? Where's her new dress?! This tense face-off is interrupted by the POUNDING of the Judge's gavel. Jackson looks disapprovingly at Grace.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE JACKSON
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Good God... (leans back) Counsel approach the bench. You join us, too, Mr. Cooper. C. JAMES COOPER, Assistant Attorney General, and Jeff wal to the bench. Jeff is white with rage. Lawson looks on wi consternation.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (to Jeff) Your client don't look too alert to me, counselor.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (nervous) Perhaps, Your Honor, that's because she's been given sedatives.

dialogues.speaker: COOPER
dialogues.text: The State is outraged, your Honor!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: That's a serious accusation, young man.  47.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, your Honor. I am simply asking for a ruling on my application for habeas corpus.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Well, that's flat denied. It's obvious to anyone with eyes that Ms. Walden is in no condition to care for herself. I order that she be moved to a halfway house. Jeff, Grace, Lawson all react. In the back of the courtro sits a stoic, elderly man, MR. PHILLIPS.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (continuing; indicating) Mr. Phillips, I hereby name you guardian ad-litem to protect the interests of Ms. Walden. If you believe that interviews and involvement in controversial matters would be harmful to her, I am confident you will act appropriately.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But your Honor... The Judge bangs his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Mr. Jenkins, and you hear what I say. You are to have no further contact with Miz Walden. That means by phone or by mail or by smoke signals. You got me on that?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She's never had a hearing or a psychiatric evaluation. She's been denied...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Don't mess with me Mr. Jenkins unless you intend to embark on a new career. The Judge precipitously swivels in his chair and heads fo his chambers. Jeff is stunned, turns to see Lawson. Their eyes connect. PUSH IN on Lawson.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black and white image of the 1968 Sanitation Workers' March. At the head of the march, walking arm-in-arm, is a row of clergy. At the center of the group is Martin Luthe King. Next to him is Jim Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson sits at his desk, staring at the photo in front of him. MOVE IN TIGHT Lawson. SOUNDS of breaking glass begin to rise. SHOUTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black and white newsreel footage of the March. Then the images of rioting. Of the police. Mayhem. Then the row of Clergy marching arm-in-arm. MOVE-IN ON King and Lawson. Flash! The screen goes white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull back from the photograph to reveal that it rests on desk. Lawson sits quietly, anguished by the memory. The room is lit only by candles.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Were you back with Martin, again? Lawson turns to see his wife has entered the study.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: No... no... just thinking.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I'm going home. Gotta get the tax records together. Clarence said the power company still hasn't showed up. He's checking the cable himself.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Thanks. He seems down and she knows her man.  49.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault, baby.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know... I know.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: We'll get through it. We always have before. She kisses him on the top of the head and leaves. Lawson sits back and looks at the picture of Martin.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Am I doing right here, Martin? I feel like I'm messing up... (a beat) Gimme a sign, Brother. And right then, the lights come back on.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I got 'em Reverend. Looks like the line was cut. A loud POP!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on a champagne bottle. The cork flies, foam spil PULL-BACK to reveal Lucas Jenkins pouring the champagne i two glasses. Jeff stands across from his father. Lucas passes him a glass. He then raises his glass to propose a toast. Jeff reluctantly follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Ubi Ius Ibi Remedium. Where law prevails, there is a remedy. To you Jeff, to your first legal victory.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Victory? I was all but run outta court.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You have to temper your idealism with practicality. The Memphis Lawyer called me for a quote. They're doing an article about you. You've come out of this just fine.  50.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You think? I can't see my client That halfway house could be just another locked room. I'll never know, because I've been prohibited from contacting her.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Grace will be just fine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You don't know that! You went to Lawson to have me pulled off the case. Didn't you?! Then you went to Branson. (no response) That was your idea, the halfway house? You went behind my back.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I protected your back! I'm trying to operate in your best interest.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I have a client. She happens to be my first client and my only client. She's not crazy. She doesn't need a halfway house. She needs her freedom.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: And you need to stop being so damn naive! Lawson just wanted a white face to walk into court. He knew about the strings attached to Grace Walden, about Charlie Stephens and James Earl Ray and the whole cesspool of lunatic conspiracy theories. He set you up. And he'll drag you down with him. Jeff turns, leaving his father alone. Prelap SOUND of a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson opens the front door and finds Jeff standing on hi front porch.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We need to talk. He pushes his way into the house. Lawson follows.  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. Lawson closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: This isn't about Grace Walden at all, is it?! Grace is your star witness! You're trying to use her to reopen the King case.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: To begin with, lower your voice. I have children sleeping. Jeff takes a deep breath, nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Secondly, wWimmresked you to go up to Bolivar? I just asked you to file a writ.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (still pissed) She was my client. I can't file papers on her behalf without talking to her first.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Sure you can. She was denied due process. Write a writ, plain and simple. File it. Instead, because you went up there, you got them all riled up. Now she's locked away in some halfway house and we'll never get her testimony.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You never gave a damn about her For you this was just about the King assassination!

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You're wrong, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah? Why now? It's been eight years. Case closed.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Wrong! The climate has changed. Hoover's dead. We're out of Viet Nam.  52.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now the public's beginning to ask questions. People are organizing. There's a petition drive - demanding that the Congress set up a committee to investigate. The time is right. We have to do it now.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We? You presume that "we" includes the young white attorney who was dumb enough to run a key part of your case by a genteel white judge? Right?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: A Black attorney would be viewed differently. It would look more like politics than law.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It is politics. It's nothing but politics. (a beat.) My father is right. I'm one naive bastard.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: There's much more at stake here than your feelings. Martin was murdered. He was assassinated and the wrong man is in jail for it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You wanted me to return the tape. Here it is! He reaches into his pocket, pulls out an audio tape.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) The first one was gibberish. This one tells it all. Take it, I won't need it anymore. He hands Lawson the tape, gets up and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on a triangle of balls. A cue ball smacks into the pack. Jeff is shooting a solitary game of Eight Ball. He' a lone white face in the run down joint. On the TV screen over the bar, the local TV station is on.  53.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: AS we approach the eighth anniversary of Dr. King's assasSination, our reporter, Terri Chambers, has assembled a tribute to this great American. On the TV, a montage special of King.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, well well... Jeff turns to see Harold. He is sharply dressed. Harold i barely recognizable as the Jenkins' humble houseman. He holds a cue case.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's they MORE) Ya gotta bring some ass to whup some ass! Must be ass-whupping time.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (down) Ain't been that time for a while Poppa H.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (putting cue together) Well, well, Mister Jeff, you not here for a whuppin'? (no response) You here about that pretty girl? (no response) Must be serious. We better rack "em up. Collecting the balls in the triangle. The TV keeps rollin the clips. The immediate image shows the chaos right afte King's killing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You go to Lawson's church, right?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Deacon's Board. Eleven years now.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What's with that guy?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: The Reverend? (Jeff nods)  54.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lawson's a heavyweight. Studied at that Ghandi School in India. Taught nonviolence to all them students that integrated in Selma, Montgomery...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But what about all the conspiracy stuff? I mean, seems a little, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: or you don't want to know? (Jeff is caught like a deer in headlights) Scary, ain't it? This here's the land of the free... the home of the brave, huh? One nation, with liberty and justice for all! Wake up, boy! Jeff has been so accustomed to seeing Harold as the deferential houseman, that the sudden revelation of Harol political cynicism is disorienting.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (continuing; lines up his break) You busy tomorrow, ‘round 8PM? Jeff nods. Harold breaks. The balls scatter. On the TV-a powerful image of King.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: (footage) The goal of life is not to seek pleasure or pain. The goal of life is to do God's work, come what may... Jeff looks intently at the screen. King alive, vital.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of light reveals a slide-projector. ANOTHER SLIDE pops onto the large screen: a closer shot of King, dead. A large sign tells us we are at MEMPHIS STATE UNIVERSITY. Only a handful of STUDENTS, mostly black, are in attendan From a light booth, an AIDE punches up slides onto a scre  55. The spill of light reveals DICK GREGORY, as he concludes lecture.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: .. Next!

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who did it? I don't know. But I do know that before you can discover the who, you have to understand the why.

dialogues.speaker: TO THE HELMETED POLICE.
dialogues.text: Jeff and Harold standmogrehe back of the auditorium, listening.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Dr. King came to Memphis to march with the striking workers. He came because Reverend James Lawson begged him to come.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE 4
dialogues.text: Jeff is taken by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (continuing) "I am aman!" Martin came to Memphis so that sanitation workers could have the simple right to use the city's toilets instead of a tin can in the cab of their truck!

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Mr. Gregory, are you saying Dr. King was killed by someone opposed to the strike?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: No. Memphis was the scene of the crime, but it wasn't the cause. The cause lay in Washington. Dr. King had organized a Poor People's March.  56.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People, maybe millions, were going to set up a tent city right in the heart of the Capitol. (wipes his brow) Martin intended to stay in DC until the economic order of this country was changed. And that terrified the authorities. It was sedition. It was insurrection! The images on the screen continue to change, giving visua dimension to Gregory's narrative.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Exactly one month before the assasSination, J. Edgar Hoover wired every FBI office: "Prevent the rise of a black Messiah". Washington, D.C. was Jerusalem to Martin Luther King - and to John Edgar Hoover. The lights go up. The lean, intense Gregory "preaches" an teaches to the hushed audience.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Martin King was assassinated because he was a dreamer, a drum major, for all people's Human Rights! And those responsible for his death didn't just kill the dreamer - they wanted to kill the dream! We have to press for the truth. We have to relight the flame! Sign the petition. We can force the Congress to investigate Dr. King's murder. A bell RINGS. Lecture is over. Harold looks at Jeff, then turns and walks away. Jeff stands shell-shocked, inert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is dispersing after the lecture. Gregory walks carrying his slides and notes. Jeff is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Gregory...?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm running late.  57.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm Grace Walden's attorney. Gregory stops, looks back at Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: You know where I can reach her? We need her testimony.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure that Ray didn't do it. They found the gun with his prints on it.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: That they did. That fact alone points to his innocence. Jeff appears confused. Pre-lap SOUNDS of running feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on running feet. A shadowy figure emerges from the entrance of the rooming house. In his right hand, he carr a rifle wrapped in a blanket. The figure turns left onto Street, drops the package in plain view and runs on.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Assume Ray did carefully plot the killing, why in hell would he drop the gun with his fingerprints on it right outside the rooming house?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: That rifle was such an obvious plant, I'm surprised nobody watered it. (growing impatient) Look, the committee is about to hire a Special Counsel. Edward Ennis. He was Solicitor General under FDR. He'll need to interview Grace.  58.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: My client has been involuntarily committed to an institution. My only concern is her freedom...

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: You can't really be that naive. Grace Walden is a political prisoner. You'll never get her justice until you deal with the larger issue. She's the key to this whole case. I need to talk to her!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Not going to happen. Jeff turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a persistent BANGING on the door. Jim Lawson move through the shot, belting a robe, he is half-asleep as he leans down and looks through the peep hole.

dialogues.speaker: FISH EYE
dialogues.text: Standing on his porch in the rain. His hair and clothes dripping wet.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME LAWSON
dialogues.text: He opens the door, reveals Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I have one question...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Come out of the rain, boy. Jeff moves into the house and begins puddling on the floo the entry hall. Lawson tosses him a towel.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: If Dick Gregory and the others can get Congress to open up an investigation and if Grace were to testify, could they protect her... keep her from being locked up in another nut house?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: It's the Congress of The United States of America.  59.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They can do anything they want. (beat) We've already contacted a very eminent jurist to be Counsel...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I know. Edward Ennis. (Lawson is surprised) You don't need eminent! You need a killer, a pit bull.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Richard Sprague is in town for the Bar Association Convention... (a beat) He took on Tony Boyle and the whole corrupt Mine Workers Union and beat them to a pulp. (beat) You hire Sprague, and I'm with you on this.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (pauses) Because of what happened to Martin, or what happened to Grace?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I promised my client her freedom... so far, I haven't kept my word. Lawson chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I'll have to make some calls, but if Sprague is available and willing, we'll go with him. Jeff exhales. That settles it. He turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
