dialogues.text: I'm gonna go rescue my client from that halfway house.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You're going to kidnap her?  60.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm going to liberate her.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Son, slow down here, for a minute. You been drinking haven't you? You're going to defy a court order? You could go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought about that... and that's a drag. Lawson hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Hold on, a minute, I'm coming with you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You gonna try to talk me out of it?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Somebody needs to say prayers over this damn fool idea. Lawson heads off to change. MOVE IN ON Jeff, still wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Grace, talking on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Of course I recognize your voice. (beat) I don't think I can do that. (beat) Red. All right. Goodbye. WIDEN TO REVEAL the MATRON in the room, listening.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Matron) That was my uncle. He wants me to knit him a sweater. He likes red.

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: I took the call downstairs. Sounded like a young man to me...  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff hangs up a pay phone and walks back, across the stre Lawson is sitting in his W, parked behind a new red Chevy rental car. The rain has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She'll be out front in fifteen minutes. Maybe a prayer about now would help. Lawson puts the WW in gear and pulls out. Jeff walks to t rental car, gets in and hangs a U, going in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red rental car pulls up in front of the Halfway House

dialogues.speaker: ON GRACE
dialogues.text: She is seated on the top step, knitting. A large paper shopping bag is beside her. As soon as she sees the red c Grace grabs the bag, darts down the steps and jumps into car. It screams away. The Matron runs after

dialogues.speaker: THE MATRON
dialogues.text: takes a pen and a pad from her pocket and tries to jot do the license plate number of the vehicle but Jeff has remo the plate. (He's learning the tricks).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red car makes a right turn at the next corner, then a left. It pulls up alongside Lawson's parked car. Jeff and Grace exit the red car and walk forward to the W. Lawson sits in the driver's seat. Next to him is a burly BLACK MAN. The Black Man exits the W and walks toward Jef They exchange a word. The Black Man then moves to the red car, gets behind the wheel and drives away. Jeff and Grace enter the W and Lawson drives away.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Grace, this is Reverend Lawson. He's the one who asked me to be your attorney.  62.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: God bless you, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Grace. (a beat) We've arranged a place for you to stay. We can only use it for a coupla' days, but we'll find a more permanent place. The main thing is, you'll be protected. Grace appears relieved. They pull out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The W pulls up. The SOUND of another car approaching gets Jeff's attention. TWO BLACK MEN drive up and park. They g out and approach Jeff. Grace looks at the men with concer

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: These men were part of the Sanitation Workers' Strike. Dr King came to Memphis to help them. They're going to take turns keeping an eye on the house. Grace nods courteously to the two men.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We're going to need you to tell your story.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I won't say I saw something I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That's what we're counting on. Jeff hugs Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Backlit Man is seated at his desk. The door opens and AGENT enters, stands with his back to the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: The Matron confirmed it. Grace Walden's gone.  63.

dialogues.speaker: BACKLIT MAN
dialogues.text: Young Mr. Jenkins had a promising career. You have the file?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a polished conference table. The Memphis Lawyer hits the shiny surface and slides across the table. We FOLLOW IT and PAN UP to Katy, who is standing in the offi looking at an angry William Branson.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: You said you'd get us some press Miss Bolton, but this sure as hell, isn't what I had in mind. She picks it up. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't waste your time. It's not a pleasant read. They stand there for a long moment, trading looks.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Frankly, I'm confused. Your people are always griping about lack of opportunity. And here you are, at a prestigious firm, where you have a chance to advance your race. And, what do you do with it? (he points at article) You jeopardize this firm's reputation and your own reputation for what? A crazy old lady. (a beat) Jeff Jenkins is listening to you and Lawson and all the rest of your people involved in this...

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Sir...

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Let me finish. If Jeff is involved in the kidnapping of this woman, he will be disbarred and, likely jailed. (a beat)  64.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I expect you to talk sense into that boy or don't bother to come back here tomorrow morning. (a beat) We've done our part. Now, dammit, you do yours. Katy stands, her expression unflinching.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jeff and Lawson approach the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (low) Sprague may be the best criminal prosecutor in the country. He's only in town for a few days...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You don't have to sell me, son. Sell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON RICHARD SPRAGUE. 40's, well-tailored. Tough as nails.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: It's kinda off my beat...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: My young friend here, tells me you're ... the best criminal prosecutor in the country. Jeff gives Lawson a look

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: (a smile) I see... (a beat) Who knows about this meeting, tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Besides us, just Congressman Fauntroy. He's in charge of the House Committee.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark-colored, windowless VAN is parked at the curb. A MIDDLE AGED WHITE MAN wearing a suit approaches the van. carries three cups of coffee. He taps on the rear door. I opens. He steps inside. The door slides shut, WIPING FRAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jeff crosses frame. REVEAL Sprague, now with his tie o holding the folder.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: You realize that everyone who tries to prove a political conspiracy ends up being labeled a crackpot - or worse.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I've lived with that a while.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Would you at least meet with Grace? I can have her here in ten minutes. She's been waiting to tell her story for eight years.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: Let me get back to you. No need to rush into this. There's plenty of time. Lawson reaches into his pocket and pulls out an envelope hands it to Sprague.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: This arrived at my church yesterday. Sprague opens the envelope, withdraws a note. A small cylindrical object drops onto the coffee table. It is a . caliber bullet. The note is in block letters and reads:

dialogues.speaker: RESUME ALL
dialogues.text: Jeff looks at Lawson. Sprague is clearly troubled.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: So you're saying there's not that much time after all....  66.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I'd sort of like to be around to see how it comes out. Sprague heaves a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neon signs flash from outside. Jeff's shirt sleeves are rolled up. He is pacing in the small living room of the suite. Lawson is seated, weary of Jeff's anxiety. LOW TON murmur from the adjoining bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Will you just sit down. Lawson reaches into a nightstand, withdraws a Gideon Bibl

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Here. Read. It'll calm you down.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (takes the book) The Bible?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Try Genesis. Chapter 37.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (finds the spot) "And when they saw him afar off..." You've got to be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Read. Jeff sits, and, what the hell, he reads. After a moment, door opens, REVEALING Grace for a minute. Then Sprague co into the living room and closes the door, shutting Grace view.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: Lemme ask you a question... Does she always take her teeth out when she's talking to strangers?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Shit.  67.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: She's an endearing old lady but she's fragile.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: She's been isolated for eight years...

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: I can't go to the Congress with theories. I gotta have witnesses. Witnesses who can stand up to the most intense cross examination.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Tell us who you need, and we'll try to get them for you.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: That's your job. You find the witnesses that make your case and bring them to me.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Can we tell Fauntroy you're our attorney?

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: Not yet. Right now let's say, I'm willing to be convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace is being put into the car and driven off by the Sanitation Workers who are guarding her. TEN other PEOPLE and a DOORMAN are milling in front of the Hotel. Jeff and Lawson stand in the entry watching in silence as windowless van pulls out to follow Grace.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He sees the van and runs out into the street, blocking it way. It slams on the brakes. (They won't hit him in front ten witnesses). The car with Grace turns the corner and i gone. The window of the van rolls down. A MAN leans out angrily.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Get outta' the way asshole!!  68. Enough time has passed so Jeff walks back and rejoins Law The van goes up the street, but they have lost the chance follow.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Where you going? We need to find witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, you need to find witnesses. I need to find a more permanent place for Grace to stay. Jeff starts to walk off into the night

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Hey!... I wanna to hire you. (Jeff turns) I want you to be my Counsel.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I thought I destroyed your case. Why would you want to hire a screw up like me?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (smiles) I admire your dedication to your clients. I'm offering you a job. Start your meter.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What about Grace? As part of my fee, can you arrange a place for Grace to live?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: ...With meals included. There is a beat. Finally Lawson smiles. Then, he and Jeff shake hands.  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Choir can be heard rehearsing Gospel music upstairs. Lawson is going through old newspaper clippings on the assassination. Brother Clarence escorts Katy in and motio to Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I'm looking for Jeff. Lawson turns.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Katy. Jeff isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Where is he? With Grace?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: At the coroner's office. You don't approve of Jeffrey's involvement in all this, do you?

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Kidnapping is a serious crime.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, sometimes power concedes nothing without demand.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: You're preaching to the wrong sister, Reverend. I lost my father to talk like that. She moves deeper into the room.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Praying has kept my family on their knees for a long time. (a beat) Up until a couple of hours ago, I had the opportunity to maybe, one day, effect change from within the system. You can run around, trying to beat the doors down from the outside, and all you do is make a lot of noise. Insiders can open those doors.  70.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: True. But, "What does it profit a man, if he gains the whole world and loses his soul"... Mark Eight, Chapter Thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: "A man can't ride your back if you're standing up straight" ...Martin Luther King, April 15, 1967. Jeff comes down the stairs, two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hey, I found something... (sees Katy) Katy, good you're here. Look at this. The slug that the Coroner removed from the body was in one piece. Holds up a picture of the autopsy photo.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) The Coroner confirms it. But the slug that the FBI Lab used for a ballistic's test was in three pieces. That means there's a massive break in the chain of evidence.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Don't jump to conclusions.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who's jumping?! The FBI tried to match the rifle that was found in front of the rooming house to the death slug. There was no match. Katy, they can't prove that the gun with Ray's fingerprints on it is the murder weapon! He looks at Katy, then Lawson. They're not with him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is big. You two seem underwhelmed. Did I miss something?  71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Katy are exiting the Church, walking to her car.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: : I'm not running. I'm just not going to be a part of a kidnapping.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Look, even if none of this bullshit is true, she's a poor woman who's been institutionalized without due process.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: It's easy for you to play semantics. You're a nice liberal white boy with no damn idea of what it's like out there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What about Grace Walden? what's it like for her?

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: Don't tell me about Grace. I've got a family full of Grace waldens and they scrubbed floors to send me to college. I'm the first one out. Understand?. The farthest you're gonna fall, is your daddy's country club. (a beat) I'm sorry, Jeff, I can't afford to be a part of this. She moves away from him and gets in her car and drives of leaving him standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas is seated at the outdoor bar, overlooking the lusci fairways. He's having a lemonade after finishing his morn golf. Bill Branson sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: We just lost the State Employees Pension Fund and the Southern Utilities accounts. He drops a copy of The Memphis Lawyer on the table.  72.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing) And it's only Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (shaken) Jesus... I'll talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: It's too late for that. This could take us all down. He gets up and exits, passing a WAITER who comes up to th table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Phone call for you, Mr. Jenkins.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Who is it.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Your son. There is a long, reflective moment.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Tell him I already left.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: He said it's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I'm not here. The Waiter hesitates, then leaves. MOVE IN on Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK HAND in a dark closet thrusts through objects to grasp a long map carton.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I was with Memphis PD for 20 years. I was in charge of security for Dr. King every time he came to Memphis. The speaker is ED REDDITT (40s), a Memphis Police Detecti black; handsome; very intense. Reverend Lawson and Jeff s Jeff has his tape recorder running as Redditt unrolls a L MAP from the carton and spreads it on his desk.  73. Lawson and Jeff rise to stand over it. (See Map in Append Redditt picks up a handful of white pieces from a CHESS S and positions them on the map.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: This was my assignment. Here's the Lorraine Motel. Walden and Stephens were in the rooming house, here. According to the FBI, the gunman was over here. He picks up the black chess king and places it on the diagram.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: (continuing) And King was here. Up until that evening, FBI agents were right here. He picks up a handful of pieces and places more white paw around the perimeter. Only the white queen remains in his hand. He looks at it, as do Jeff and Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What's with the white queen?

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: No. Hoover wasn't there. Lawson gives a huge chuckle, breaking the tension for a moment. As Redditt resumes, moving pieces, Jeff and Lawso crowd in closer.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: (continuing) My normal security detail consisted of ten men. But they cut me back to two. ‘bout an hour before the killin', the Chief sent for me. It was like a meeting of the Joint Chiefs of Staff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large conference room filled with men seated at a table some wearing high-ranking police brass and uniforms, othe in plainclothes, stand off to the side. Director of Fire Police FRANK HOLLOMAN presides over the meeting. Ed Reddi has just been brought in by LIEUTENANT ARKIN.  74.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOMAN
dialogues.text: Ed, these gentleman are from the FBI. They have information that a group in Mississippi has a contract out to kill you. So, you go on home now and stay there.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: Chief, I can't leave Officer Richmond alone.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOMAN
dialogues.text: That's an order, and there's nothing to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: Two Memphis police officers took me home, and remained with me in the house.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You were under "house arrest"?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Redditt -- what ever happened to this contract on your life?

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: After the assassination, no one ever said another word about it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: And would you be willing to testify to that? In front of Congress?

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: Man, I've carried this with me for too long... Yeah. I'd testify. Jeff picks up several white pawns. He points to the area the diagram that shows the fire station.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wouldn't the firemen have seen something? Jeff puts down the white pawns at the fire station. Reddi smiles, picks up two black knights and places them, also, the fire station.  75.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: Especially the black firemen. If they'd been there. (to Lawson) Remember Floyd Newsum?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. He helped organize the sit- in for the sanitation workers.

dialogues.speaker: REDDITT
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not the only one who's fed- up with all the lies. Talk to Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mississippi River. A stocky black man, FLOYD NEWSUM, tossing stones into the tolling river. Lawson and Jeff st behind him.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSUM
dialogues.text: I should've been there! I would've seen the killer!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why weren't you at the firehouse?

dialogues.speaker: NEWSUM
dialogues.text: Because my supervisor called me at 10:30 at night -- to tell me that I was transferred. Me and Norvil Wallace. We were the only two black firemen at Station 2.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Maybe they needed you somewhere else...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSUM
dialogues.text: No, Reverend: I was sent toa station that was over staffed. Understand? So was Norvil. We had no assignment. But at Number Two, they were so short-handed that the equipment was "inoperable for lack of personnel." Jeff and Lawson exchange a look

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What men had the power to move Fire and Police Officers around like that?  76.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSUM
dialogues.text: Not men. Man.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Frank Holloman.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: In the history of Memphis, for a brief period of time, there was one man who was the Director of both Fire and Police.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Was Holloman working for the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: NEWSUM
dialogues.text: Best ask Arthur Murtaugh. He was with the bureau over twenty years. He's retired. Might be willing to talk. (to Jeff) You married?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSUM
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Lawson are working together. The office has been turned into a war room. Jeff reads from a file on King while eating one of Sister Ione's delicious pies.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I can't believe this stuff. They let King sit in jail with a broken arm? That's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: That's real. Once Martin went toa maximum security prison for a traffic ticket. Lawson moves to the bulletin board and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) What about Charlie Q. Stephens?  77.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: If Sprague thought Grace was fragile, he's gonna love Charlie. Besides, Charlie Q. Stephens didn't witness dogshit. (off Lawson's look) A quote from the honorable Lucas Jenkins.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, Murtaugh sounds promising. Jeff starts on another pie as: Dorothy opens the door and sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Sister Ione is out here, baby. She needs to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Oh no... not now.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I've put her off twice already.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (licking his fingers) Is that the lady with the pies? Get us another peach cobbler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reverend emerges from his office.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Sister Ione, what can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: TONE
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) I'm so sorry, Reverend, but I can't come here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Willie didn't get his solo? I'll talk to Brother Boxer.

dialogues.speaker: IONE
dialogues.text: No... It ain't safe here.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Not safe?  78.

dialogues.speaker: TONE
dialogues.text: My sister went to 16th Street Baptist back in Birmingham. You remember? (a beat) Some of us been gettin' phone calls... and then, there're those men taking pictures...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: What men? Whatta you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I tried to tell you about that earlier, honey. There're two men out in the parking lot. Taking pictures of license plates. He starts down the hall and out of the Church. Dorothy ca after him.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jim! But... he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are TWO MEN in gray suits moving around with camera One is taking pictures of car license plates. Several of Church faithful are getting into cars and pulling out. So are standing around watching, not sure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Moves directly towards the men, who ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH MEMBER
dialogues.text: (as Lawson goes by) Who are they, Reverend? Lawson doesn't respond. He stops in front of them and snatches the camera out of the surprised Agent's hand.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: That's government property. Lawson strips the film out of the camera, then tosses the camera back. It hits the man in the chest.  79.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing) You just made a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Unless you have business here, you are trespassing on private property. You can get the hell out of this parking lot. A couple of the BIG CHURCH MEMBERS take their lead from L and move in. The two Agents look around at the angry blac faces. The Agents back up, get into their car and pull ou Lawson takes the film and walks past the Church Members.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Choir practice starts in ten minutes, Brother Boxer is waiting. He heads back into the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson comes in and slams the door. He's still hot. Jeff has watched it all from the office window.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What part of the infant were you looking at out there? Lawson drops the film in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Sometimes I do it better than others. He pauses, then turns and faces Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Murtaugh lives in upstate New York. I got problems here. You'll have to go see him by yourself. You okay with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR MURTAUGH (50s) is a shrewd, experienced veteran. H hands tremble, his face is mottled, he cannot forget  80.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: I was assigned to the Field Office in Atlanta. For ten years I was part of COINTELPRO.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: Surveillance and harassment. And whatever else Hoover deemed necessary to derail the Civil Rights Movement. Jeff is shaken.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Whatever else...?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: Whatever. Remember the four little girls who were killed by a bomb in Birmingham? 1963? (Jeff nods) We had clear, conclusive evidence on the killers. Hoover halted the investigation. Hid the evidence. No one questioned his authority.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Murtaugh, did you know Frank Holloman?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: Sure. Holloman was the Inspector in charge of the "S.0.G." (Jeff looks puzzled) "The Seat of Government" -- that's what Mr. Hoover called his office. In Hoover's mind, even the President reported to him. Holloman was Hoover's man.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He saw Hoover every day?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: He did. So did I -- at one point I saw him. I saw it. I saw the hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is dark except for the beam of the film projec Murtaugh and several OTHER AGENTS sit in the deep shadows watching. The agents are arranged around the raised desk chair of J. EDGAR HOOVER the man in darkness, who sits as locked onto the image on the screen of MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. Hoover, squat and seething, is immobile in the light spil His voice is a steady subterranean stream of filth:

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Commonist. Pervert. Traitor...

dialogues.speaker: DR. KING
dialogues.text: "A few years ago, it seemed as if there was a real promise of hope for the poor, both black and white... And then came the build- up of Viet Nam. And I watched this promise broken..."

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Like a litany, the invective grinds out, sibilant and raw

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Weakling. Anarchist...

dialogues.speaker: DR. KING
dialogues.text: "The poor people's March on Washington will demand total, direct, and immediate abolition of poverty."

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: This -- is -- commonism!

dialogues.speaker: DR. KING
dialogues.text: "We seek to say to the nation that if you don't straighten up, then you're writing your own obituary. We must love each other, or perish."

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Love the white women -- whoremonger !  82. Hoover pounds his desk violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes do not leave Murtaugh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Did Hoover hate King enough to have him killed?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: At first he thought that he could assassinate King's character -- his reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murtaugh and TWO other AGENTS stand while Hoover sits and listens to a TAPE -- a tape with MUFFLED SOUNDS that are completely incoherent.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: . Where's this one from?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Stockholm. Hoover beats on the table, his voice choked.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: They gave that whoremaster the Nobel Prize! Hoover wipes his hands; slips a mint into his mouth; juts his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Next! Agent Two puts on a second tape: breathing, SOUNDS of BEDSPRINGS, soft laughter.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Turn it up... more... louder!  83. Hoover listens to what may be the sounds of sexual intercourse. He is clearly excited. The Agents avert thei eyes from the terrible scene.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Again. Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: Well, sir, it's actually Reverend Abernathy's room, but he --

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: It's King!... I know King.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Hoover rises, snarlingyorE)

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Send it to King with a letter saying if he doesn't kill himself, we'll release it to the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start tight on Jeff's incredulous expression.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: They didn't actually send...

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: We did. Had it postmarked in Atlanta, but it was written in D.C.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who authorized the wiretaps?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: The Attorney General. Bobby Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I thought Bobby hated Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: He did, but he loved his own brother more. (letting it sink in) We wired King for years.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hoover forced Bobby to sign off on it. Blackmailed him with tapes of Jack... in inappropriate circumstances. Hoover had tapes on everybody. Then something happened.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Tight on television. Lyndon Johnson is speaking straight into camera.

dialogues.speaker: LBJ
dialogues.text: . What we won when all of our people united must not now be lost... Acqmokmgly, I shall not seek, and I will not accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your President...

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why didn't I know about this? Widen to show Hoover. A nervous Agent stands to one side.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Nobody did, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: That little bastard, Bobby! If he thinks I'll let him be President...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Sir, Senator Kennedy has been trying to call Dr. King. We think he might offer King the Vice President slot.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: That is not going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: Hoover was in a panic. If Kennedy was elected, Hoover was finished. The Poor People's March was just a month off.  85.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For Hoover it was a state of National Emergency. Then King signed his own death warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover, Murtaugh and three other agents are listening toa TAPE RECORDING of Dr. King:

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: (on tape) . The efforts by the FBI to destroy our movement by peddling gossip about my sex life must be exposed.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: (on tape) You cannot do this, Martin. It's suicide.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: (on tape) We can weather any storm. I must make a public confession even if it means that the Movement goes on without me.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: (on tape) There is no Movement without you.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: (on tape; laughing) There'd better be. Anyway, I appreciate your counsel, but my mind is made up. Murtaugh rises and lunges out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murtaugh turns away from Jeff, as if ashamed by what he remembers so clearly.  86.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: King was different than the others. Simple character assassination wouldn't be enough to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murtaugh and several OTHER AGENTS are seated in chairs in front of Hoover's desk. They bend forward like slaves waiting for their master's pronouncement

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: What hotel is King staying in?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: In Memphis, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, for goodness sake!

dialogues.speaker: 1ST AGENT
dialogues.text: Rivermont. Here's a photograph, sir The Agent places a BLOW-UP of the Holiday Inn Rivermont o easel. The photo, taken from a distance, shows the isolat of the large structure. Hoover shakes his head negatively

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: No good. Get him out of there.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: Well, sir, we have a plan that --

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Let me hear it.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: We thought of a campaign in the news media to point out that King wants to stay in a luxury white hotel while there are Negro-owned hotels that are suffering for lack of business.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Good. Wants to conduct a "lay-in" there. Hoover smiles slightly, the others follow suit.  87.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing) What Negro motels offer the best opportunity?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: We think the Lorraine Motel, sir. The Second Agent places a BLOW-UP of the Lorraine Motel o the easel.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: What's across the street from it?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: There's an embankment --

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: A bank?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, I meant to say an embankment -- a cliff --

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: I know what an embankment is!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: On top of the, uh, embankment are some rooming houses and at the corner is a fire station.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: They have Negro firemen there?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND AGENT
dialogues.text: We'll find that out, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Well, what's the plan to get him into the Negro motel?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD AGENT
dialogues.text: We have prepared editorials that will be placed with sympathetic media outlets. A cooperative Senator might even be persuaded to read the release into the record. The Third Agent passes the speech.  88.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Let me see it... "This self- seeking rabble rouser..." As Hoover reads the speech, overlap Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a 1968 Memphis newspaper editorial calling for K to stay at the Lorraine, which Jeff holds in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (reading) ",... rabble rouser will not share the squalor of his followers. Instead, he will be conducting a lay-in at a posh hotel..." Jeff sets the clipping down.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: We packed the papers with editorials. Finally King cancelled his reservations at the Holiday Inn and booked rooms at the Lorraine Motel... And it was built like a shooting gallery...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: Strange thing was, the King party was originally booked on the ground floor in the back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DARK-SKINNED MAN of East Indian appearance walks toward manager's office.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...The motel owner said that a man came by the office and asked that the King party be moved to the second floor, to room 306. The man knocks on the Manager's door. A black woman opens the door and listens to the man's instructions.  89.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH, (V.0)
dialogues.text: (continuing) No one connected with SCLC knows who that man was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sits quietly.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: That last night, King went to speak at a church. His regular driver, Solomon Jones, drove him. I was on surveillance outside the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murtaugh sits in his unmarked FBI car. Detective Redditt sits in his unmarked MPD car, across the street. Each is conducting surveillance. Rain pours down.

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was pouring rain... From the church come SHOUTS of "AMEN." THUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: "... Well, I don't know what will happen now. We've got some difficult days ahead. But it doesn't matter with me now. Because I've been to the mountain top. And I don't mind. Like anybody, I would like to live a long life. Longevity has its place. But I'm not concerned about that now. I just want to do God's will. And He's allowed me to go up to the mountain. And I've looked over."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heartbreaking last oration of MLK reaches out to the street, as do SOUNDS of the CONGREGATION... RAIN and THUN Murtaugh and Redditt sit in their separate vehicles.  90.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: (continuing) "... and I've seen the Promised Land. I may not get there with you. But I want you to know tonight, that we, as a people, will get to the Promised Land!..."

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Did Hoover have him killed?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: He wanted him dead. I don't know if he ordered the killing. But I know he did nothing to stop it. (overwhelmed) They hated him. And they never stopped, not even after he was dead. That's why there was no real investigation. Our Security Squad was assigned by Hoover to destroy King's legacy, to destroy his widow's reputation...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Would you testify to that?

dialogues.speaker: MURTAUGH
dialogues.text: I'll say what I know. But if you want all the answers, you'll have to subpoena the files. All the files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The setting sun casts erie shadows. Jeff and Lawson walk the embankment just below the room where Grace once lived

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Did he seem credible?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You'll never find a better witness than Arthur Murtaugh. He has notes, a good memory, anda conscience. And he has guts.  91. The Reverend looks at his protege, his smile matures into low laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: And so do you. Jeff looks up at the bathroom window of the rooming house (the room from which Ray supposedly fired the shot).

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's the window where James Earl Ray supposedly perched on a bathtub and shot King.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Looks like a clear shot.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: It's a question of tense.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: It's a clear shot now. But was it a clear shot on April 4th, 1968?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close On a blur of black and white images. The WHIRRING sound of a microfiche machine is evident. The scrolling images slow and finally stop.

dialogues.speaker: ON JEFF
dialogues.text: Bent over the machine. One image has caught his eye: A black and white photograph of the Rooming House as viewed from the Lorraine. Trees and bushes grow on the embankmen obscuring the sightline from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: God bless the Associated Press. This image was taken March 29, a week before the shooting.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Look at that tree. Jeff makes some notes and focuses on a short article, whi Lawson pours over files.  92.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Listen to this. (he starts reading) Press Scimitar. Kay Pitnam Black. "On the advice of former Mayor Bill Ingram, I went to the rooming house the morning after the assassination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A city maintenance crew is working with mowers and chain saws.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A city maintenance crew was cutting down the bushes on the embankment..." Kay Black is across the street, a notepad in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Why'd the cops let them destroy a crime scene? Jeff doesn't respond. He is reloading the machine and searching for something. Finding it, he turns to Lawson.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear of a reporter for the New York Times named Caldwell?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Earl Caldwell. There weren't many black reporters working for The Times back then.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (reading) "I was staying in Room 215...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EARL CALDWELL, black, thirtysomething, stands in the door of Room 215 on the ground level of the Lorraine.  93. He's enjoying the evening breeze. An explosive SOUND. Caldwell is startled. He turns and looks across Mulberry Street.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . After the shot, I looked up to see a white male, dressed in coveralls in the bushes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An area of brush surrounds the sloping area at the rear o the rooming house. A white male wearing coveralls is crouched in the bushes. There is no gun evident.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0)
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...A black sedan drove directly in front of me, cutting off my view. The man vanished over the embankment. The sedan kept moving, back and forth... Caldwell's line of sight is blurred by a black sedan that passes frantically back and forth in front of the motel. Tires SQUEAL. Caldwell looks at the car, then back to the bushes. The man is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson reloads the machine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Caldwell wrote the story, but neither the Memphis PD nor the FBI ever questioned him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: My friend, James Orange, saw the same thing. They never questioned him, either. Lawson spins the control. Zeroes in on something.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look at this. CLOSE-UP: A black and white image of four men kneeling on balcony, pointing.  94.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I've seen that picture before.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: It was taken seconds after the assasSination. Notice the guy on the end? Next to Ralph Abernathy. His name's Marrell McCollough.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised. Even Abernathy didn't know who he was. (Jeff is puzzled) McCollough led a group of militants. Called themselves "The Invaders". After the shooting, word started to leak out that McCollough was really an undercover cop.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Rumor is he works for the CIA.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We need proof, not rumors. Where's the phone? Jeff gets up and starts to walk away. Lawson follows.

dialogues.speaker: ON PUBLIC TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: Jeff cradles the phone to his ear. Lawson stands to one s

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (into phone) Operator, I need the area code for Langley, Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish the sprawling headquarters.  95.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (into phone) Marrell McCollough, please. (he waits) Mr. McCollough, My name is Jeff Jenkins. I'd like to ask you a few questions about the King assassination... CLICK. The phone goes dead. But Jeff has the confirmation

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: He actually answered?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yep. Your militant Invader is moving up in the world. (sits back) So, if the shot didn't come from the rooming house... if the man Grace saw was just a decoy, if the gun he dropped was just a plant... why did Ray plead guilty?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Maybe it's time we try to talk to him. The SOUND of a W engine comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson is driving his bug. Gospel music plays on his radi Jeff sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You think Ray was involved? Jim, with humor and a kind of preacher's rhythm, sets up question and response as if for the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Let's see what he could have done. Did Ray dismantle the police protection? I need a witness.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No. That was Mr. Holloman.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Say, Hallelujah. Did Ray saw down the trees? I need a witness.  96.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I can bear witness, brother. No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Say, Hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (seriously) Did Ray fire the shot? I needa witness.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: No way, brother. Ray was a bumbling burglar, not a marksman. If he was part of a plot, it's not likely he would have been the triggerman.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But Ray would be a perfect fallguy.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Say Amen, brother.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brushy Mountain Penitentiary Entrance Gate just ahead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a steel table with four chairs. There are bars o the windows and the light spills through in patterns. JAM EARL RAY is seated at the table. He is now almost fifty y old. He speaks in a soft twang. Jeff is focusing on Ray through a VIDEO CAMERA. Lawson has files in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Ray, why did you plead guilty, if you now say you're innocent?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I had to. But I told the Judge that I would not agree that there was no conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Why did you have to plead guilty?  97.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Did you ever see the cell in Memphis, where they kept me for eight months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cell is brightly lit, painted stark white. Two guards are stationed outside the cell. Television cameras are focused on Ray and are monitored in a control room by two other guards. Banks of hot lights focus on him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Eight months. They never turned out the lights. Day or night. One of the guards, he had a nervous breakdown. I thought it was going to kill me... INTERCUT Ray suffering in jail cell, 1968; and on the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) One day, this big-shot lawyer came in. He was so full of himself, he could strut sittin' down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERCY FOREMAN, the famous Texas defense lawyer, talks to

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: You know me?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I'm Percy Foreman. Without doubt the best and most famous damn criminal lawyer in the whole USA. And I'm here to tell you those free lawyers you got... They're selling you out, son.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I hear what you say. Don't mean I believe it.  98.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I can save you, boy. I have so much money, I don't need you to pay me nothing. I have defended seven hundred capital cases and every one of them is still walking around, and I mean outside, free. Well, except one, but he was a fool and didn't follow my advice.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What's your advice?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: You fire those clowns and I guarantee you'll walk out of here a free man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shadows of bars fall across Ray, Lawson and Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: After I told the judge that Foreman was my lawyer, he warned me that I couldn't ever change lawyers again. I said, "Fine. I got the best lawyer in America." Then Foreman came into my cell --

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: If you don't plead guilty, you're going to the Tennessee dance hall, boy, and that's the e-lectric chair. They'll fry you.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I didn't do nothing. Just bought a gun for a friend. That's why my prints were on it.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with the price of beer?  99.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I want a trial. My old lawyers said I could win at trial.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I didn't want to have to do this, but there's someone here to see you. The Guards watch the scene on the monitor as an FBI AGENT enters.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) This here is an FBI man. Show him your I.D. The Agent does.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Your father's a real old man, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: And he escaped from the penitentiary in Fort Madison, Iowa, in 1921, didn't he? Ray freezes. The Agent pulls out documents. Foreman light a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (continuing) We found out where he's hiding. You don't cooperate with your attorney - - we're going to send your daddy back to prison -- and let him die behind bars. Here's the warrant. Read it. Foreman spits on the floor. Ray's head drops.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: If you say you didn't kill King, you're going to get a jolt a' Edison medicine. And your Daddy will rot in the process. You let me plead the case, and they'll let you live. Ray is exhausted. He rubs his eyes in the blinding light.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: So, you pleaded guilty?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I was confused from no sleep, bein' in that white cell for months, so yeah, I confessed. That night they put me in a regular cell. I got my first night's sleep in eight months. I woke up and knew I'd made a mistake. Asked for a new trial. And that was eight years ago. Silence, except for dim PRISON SOUNDS and a far-off bell.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Why were you in Memphis on April

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I had broke out from the penitentiary in Jefferson City, Missouri, so I needed money. I never had been convicted of any crime of violence, I never even hit anyone in my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Country and Western MUSIC over entire sequence.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I knew I would have to engage in some criminal stuff to survive, but I wasn't going to do nothing violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man ("RAOUL") approaches Ray at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: How about a drink -- James? Ray jumps -- how does this stranger know his name? Ray is white with fear. (We have seen this stranger before: in t Grace Walden memory sequence. )

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Like it was a miracle, "Raoul" showed up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Who was he? What was his last name?

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don't even know his first name, he just said "Raoul." He said he had a job for me.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I went with Raoul to a car dealership. He bought me a car Everything was cash money. Raoul peels off bills, he and Ray buy a new white Mustang

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raoul and Ray drive up in the white Mustang.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He had a deal to sell rifles to some guy in Latin America. He needed a sample gun to show. But I got the wrong gun. He made me go back. Raoul shouts at Ray behind closed car windows. They get o of the car. Raoul stalks away and gets into another car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (to CLERK) Yes sir, my boss said this is the wrong kind. Shoulda asked for... (reads from a scrap of paper ) Uh, a 30.06 caliber, Remington Model 760. suspiciously eyes an insecure Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray drives alone toward Memphis in his white Mustang.  102.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I gave Raoul the gun. He then told me to rent a room in Memphis. Gave me the name of the flophouse. INT. ROOMING HOUSE -- APRIL 4, 1968 -- 5:00 P.M. Raoul passes Charlie Stephens (drunk) on the stairs of th rooming house, and heads into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sits reading a newspaper. The gun is on the bed. He looks up at Raoul. (SOUND of Charlie YELLING at Grace, o.

dialogues.speaker: RAOUL
dialogues.text: The buyer'll be here in an hour. Go take a walk. Be back at six. Leave the car and the rifle here. Ray is worried. Something is wrong. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray fills the Mustang. He is jumpy, smelling trouble.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I started to take a walk but then I remembered that there wasn't hardly any gas in the car. I knew that when Raoul finished the gun deal he'd want to drive right out.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But when I got back... The Mustang approaches, Ray at the wheel. He suddenly rea to something. RAY'S P.O.V. SIRENS, pandemonium, police.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He spins the car around and speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Did you ever think what would've happened if you had just gone for a walk?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I thought about it a lot. I would've walked back into the rooming house right after the shot was fired -- Raoul and the car would've been gone and they'd've arrested me on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: If you didn't do anything -- why did you run?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I was a fugitive -- I owed time to Missouri. If they even got me for a parking ticket, I'd probably spend the rest of my life in jail.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You remember what Raoul looked like?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: That man is cut in my memory. Ain't never gonna forget him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Was he about fifty - short, wiry - pointed chin and a pointed nose?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Now, how did you know all that?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Did he look anything like any of these three men? Jeff reaches into his briefcase and pulls out three IDENT DRAWINGS. He hands them to Ray. Ray looks at all three an pushes two of them aside. He picks one and studies it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I think this is him. At least, it sure favors him. Where'd you get it?  104.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: From a woman -- named Grace Walden.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (beat) Who's Grace Walden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Grace, animated, talking on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Well, she won't let me stop eating. (beat) Alright then. Goodbye now. Grace hangs up, smiles. WIDEN TO REVEAL Sister Ione and Willy having lunch with Grace. One of the sanitation work stands in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Ione) That was Jeff, checking on me and hoping we'd save him some pecan pie. Ione smiles, proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff hangs up the phone. Lawson and Jeff are working. The bulletin board is now covered with notes and cards.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We got plenty of witnesses, but we need more hard evidence.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Either way, we gotta go with what we got... Sprague's not going to wait around forever. The door opens and Katy appears. Both men sit in silence looking at her. She is holding a file.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Katy...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Come in, sit down.  105.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about what you said, Reverend... and you're right. I want to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: There's no need.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: I realized that the more things I wanted, the more things I was willing to compromise. (a beat) I located the police records on the Assassination. The entire file is stored in the Municipal Building on Maple.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We can get Sprague to subpoena those files. They'll corroborate everything that Redditt and Newsum told us. Those files are a gold mine.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Are we looking at a new recruit here?

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: You're looking at temporary help. It seems I'm between jobs at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choir practice is over. The CHILDREN are walking into the parking lot. Jeff and Katy exit the church and begin walk toward their cars.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: So, how's Grace?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Happy and putting on weight. Speaking of which... I'm starving. You eaten? They move across the street. The children are milling aro and we see a TRUCK in the B.G. moving slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything cranks painfully slow... The TRUCK moves towar them. We see the children laughing, walking. The truck is even with Jeff and Katy when a GRENADE flies out of the window and lands on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF AND KATY
dialogues.text: He spots the grenade. Jeff throws Katy down and dives on of her.

dialogues.speaker: TICK
dialogues.text: Play the tension. Several long beats.

dialogues.speaker: GRENADE AND CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Then Jeff gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: He moves to the grenade and kicks it with his toe. Then reaches down and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: THE GRENADE
dialogues.text: It says: G.I. JOE

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) A damn toy. Jeff hurls it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door BANGS open and Jeff strides into the house and upstairs to his old bedroom. Harold is at the far end of foyer, dusting. He looks up, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas is reading. He hears the commotion and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a drawer as Jeff rummages through it. He grabs a old pistol and slams a clip into the revolver. Widen to reveal the environs of his old room. He exits the room.  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff heads down the hall but stops suddenly. He sees his father approaching. Lucas stares at the gun in Jeff's han

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: What the devil are you doing? Jeff starts down the stairs and Lucas follows.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Stop. I need to speak to you. Whatta' you doing? Jeff has reached the downstairs landing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Non-violenq@ORe ja great concept, but I'm not signing up for it yet Jeff starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Stop. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why now? Branson lean on you?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: That's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why did you and your friends offer the money to bribe Charlie Stephens -- to lie? And why did you bury Grace in that hell hole?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You were part of it!... why?!

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I didn't know!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You didn't want to know!

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I loved Martin King. He's a page in a history book to you.  108.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was his lawyer here, his friend. I was his friend when it could cost you your life to even walk down the street with him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You know that the government killed your "friend". And that you helped to cover it up. And you're still doing it! You and Branson and the Judge --

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: When Martin died that night, the city went up in flames. The whole country was burning... President Johnson asked me to personally reassure Mrs. King that the Department (oORH)stice would "leave no stone unturned".

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) They sure did a helluva job.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: We couldn't bring him back. All we had left was the memory. And they made it plain that could be taken away, too. They had evidence against him. The FBI showed it to me! Those sons-of- bitches!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Showed you what? Lucas shakes his head and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) They played a dirty tape for you. Didn't they? Lucas looks up at Jeff, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: It was different ten years ago. Jeff... You can't imagine how powerful Hoover was. He was the secret police -- for fifty years! No one could stand up to Hoover. No one. (drops his voice)  109.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tried to tell Martin, I begged him not to mix the politics of Vietnam with Civil Rights. But he wouldn't listen. And when he tried to change the economic system - it was all over. Jeff leans in; they are face-to-face, eye-to-eye.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No. You wouldn't listen. King had already decided to go public on the question of his "marital infidelity."

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: You know that?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I've heard the FBI tape. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucas's head drops. Jeff moves in for the moment of truth his voice hoarse and charged, his breathing short.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't you see what you've done? You covered up Hoover's crimes -- not King's! Jeff moves down the stairs, where Harold opens the door f him. He has heard the entire thing. The two men lock eyes

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You be real careful out there, Mr. Jeff. Real careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is filling a briefcase with files. The SOUND of the door opening. Jeff turns to see Branson in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: There's a rumor that there'll be an announcement from Washington, that Congress will form a Select Committee to investigate the Kennedy and King murders.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm aware of that.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: We understand that Miz Walden may be called as a witness.  110.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our firm takes the position that any information you have gathered from Miz Walden belongs to us. It is privileged.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: The privilege runs to the client. It's really up to Grace.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: That old lady'1l do what you tell her! Jeff starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have you thought this out? I can destroy you. I own you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You see, that's where you're wrong, Bill. You don't own me. You gotta bring some ass to kick some ass. Jeff walks out. He walks down the corridor, past Clay Mor who has heard it all.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) He shoots. He scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves into the room and picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Lemme talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: N.D. OFFICE
dialogues.text: The Backlit Man picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BACKLIT MAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: He wouldn't listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is moving along the lower sidewalk in front of the Motel.  111.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Up here... Jeff looks up and sees Lawson and Katy. He hurries up the stairs and stops in front of the room where King was shot

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: This was King's room, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Yes. (points across the street) And there's the rooming house. And the embankment. And the fire station. It all happened right here...

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: A tightly edited, chronological reprise details everythin that has been discovered about the events.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: ...It started when the FBI forced King out of the Rivermont, got him to move to the Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then the unknown man gets the room changed from the ground floor...

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (V.0)
dialogues.text: The black cops and th.e black firemen were ordered out of the area.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ray says he got in the Mustang and left the area.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Charlie Stephens, the government's eyewitness, was outside taking a leak and saw nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katy looks at Jeff and Lawson. A car door SLAMS shut. Jef and Lawson look down.  112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fifty year old black man, SOLOMON JONES, stands by an o black town car.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (to Lawson) Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: You remember Caldwell's story... The black sedan that was driving back and forth. That's Solomon Jones. (calling out) Brother Solomon. Thanks for coming. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (to Lawson) Jim, how'd you find him?

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I've known Solomon for years. He was Martin's driver. (to Solomon) Brother Solomon, could you stand where you were that afternoon. Solomon walks to a spot about twenty yards away.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) So, Dr. King was standing right about here, where I am?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: That's right. And I was standing by the car, waiting to take him to dinner at Reverend Kyle's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones is leaning against the black sedan.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dr. King, he leaned over the railing and asked Ben Branch if later on, he would play his favorite hymn.  113.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (starts to sing) Precious Lord, take my hand... The HYMN CONTINUES OVER. King is only seen in silhouette he comes out of the door of his Lorraine Motel room. Solo Jones looks up and sees him. Starts to get into the car. SOLOMON V.O. (continuing) I went to get into the car so I could pull it up. ANGLE up to the MINISTERS on the Balcony, talking. SOLOMON V.O. (continuing) And that's when I heard the shot. In black and white, King turns and a shot rings out. The body passes through the frame.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON KING'S HAND
dialogues.text: Bloody. It lands on the deck, convulses once and lies sti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff checks his notes, standing there, lost in the moment

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: OK, Jeff, run it down from there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: The Reporter from the New York Times looked out and saw a white man dressed in coveralls, in the hedges beside the Rooming House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHITE MAN IN COVERALLS is crouched in the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Caldwell saw a puff of smoke. Then a man in coveralls jumped over the wall. The Man in coveralls jumps over the wall, starts to flee. black sedan swerves back and forth trying to pursue.  114.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I saw him too. I tried to follow him, I really did. I really tried. I was hemmed in.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Is that what you told the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: That's just it, they never talked to me. Reverend Orange, he saw the same thing and they never talked to him either. Seemed they already had their eyewitness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chaos just after the shooting. In the parking lot a c runs toward the balcony. He looks up, seems to know one o the men standing over King. CoP The shot! Where did it come from?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The guy on the end of the balcony, he points. But not to the embankment. He points to the rooming house. Abernathy and the others see him, and then they do the same thing. McCollough points to the Rooming House above the hedge. The other Reverends point there also.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: He is panicked. He sees the white Man in the coveralls ju over the wall below - clearly not where they're pointing.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) I saw the man jump off the embankment. I jumped in my car. I tried...  115. Solomon jumps into his car and tries to drive after the M but can't get the car turned around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson, Jeff and Katy are looking at Solomon, who has tea in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Solomon, that guy on the balcony, his name was Marrell McCollough. He was an undercover cop.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: The key witness was on the government's payroll?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Still is. (checks his notes) Meanwhile, Grace was in her room across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace sees a MAN run past the door of her room carrying something. The man heads outside, drops the gun. Flees.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A man flees down the hall and out of the building. A few minutes later the cops conveniently find a rifle with Ray's fingerprints left in broad daylight. A COP reaches down and picks up the bundle.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The weapon is never linked to the death slug. Reprise images of the autopsy photo and the bullet in pie

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The next morning, the City purposely alters the crime scene. Reprise images of the trees being cut down.  116.

dialogues.speaker: KATY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And, later on that summer, they came back for Grace. Reprise images of Grace being taken from her room.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They kicked down the door to her room and dragged her away. Locked her up for eight years. (a beat) And that's where this whole thing began for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Sprague. He is just finishing going through the files. Jeff, Lawson and Katy wait as he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: Pretty damn impressive. You can officially tell Fauntroy, the Committee has a Special Counsel. Lawson exhales. It's been a long road.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Okay. What about Grace Walden?

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: You can tell her she's a free woman. She doesn't have to hide from anyone. You have my word.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: What about the Memphis PD files that Katy found?

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: I'm going to file a subpoena for those. You pick ‘em up, bring 'em with you to D.C. I'm also going to file a subpoena demanding the production of all relevant documents from the FBI, the CIA and Army Intelligence. (a smile) We're going to war. Jeff and Lawson brace. This is it.  117.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A brick building in Memphis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mild looking man named BART appears flustered. Lawson, Jeff and Katy stand across from him. Jeff waves a subpoen

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Look, I've got a court subpoena. We want to see all King files.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: We were told we could pick them up from you at nine A.M. It's ten o'clock. The phone RINGS. Bart picks it up. Listens:

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay... Okay... (hangs up) We been cleared. They're in the old section. Follow me. He leads them down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING to a File Case. Bart kneels down. Three file drawers are missing from the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: The King stuff... It's all missing. Then we HEAR a commotion outside and someone yells.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: FIRE! We gotta a fire out back! Lawson moves to the window and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: THE ALLEY
dialogues.text: Two stories below. Two COPS are stoking a dumpster fire.  118.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: My lord! He turns and runs. Jeff and Katy do the same.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Jeff runs down the hall, grabs a fire extinguisher off th wall. Lawson and Katy are close behind.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Jeff explodes out into the alley. The Cops grab him and k him at bay as the trash bin blazes away. Lawson and Katy arrive. They stop. PUSH IN ON LAWSON through the flames a he watches the records burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN to a WINDOW with venetian blinds. The Backlit Man standing there, the reflection of the fire flickering in lenses of his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Katy are with Grace. Katy smiles as Grace gratefully hugs Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: My, my... a lawyer who keeps his word. (wiping her eyes) Better not let anything happen to you in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: (to Grace) I'll be here if there's anything you need.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Jeff... if you want me to come there... to testify... I can. I'll tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You always told the truth, Grace, when everybody lied -- everybody. You were the conscience of this country.  119.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You talk like that -- they're going to call you crazy, too. Jeff doesn't know whether to laugh or cry. He hugs Grace a mighty embrace. The SOUND of jet engines can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 737 approaches the runway and touches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson and Jeff run up the steps, carrying two large fold of evidence. A GUARD follows them, then ANOTHER GUARD tro up to help the first,(Miwm)a THIRD GUARD dogs their heels

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Lawson walk down a hallway. They are lost in the maze of corridors. Lawson approaches a black SECURITY GUA

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Brother, could you point us to Mr. Sprague's office? The Guard indicates the way.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Jeff and Lawson round a corner and head for Sprague's off They get to the door marked: RICHARD SPRAGUE.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Get your hands off of me. Lawson looks to Jeff with concern. They enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson and Jeff enter to see Sprague being forcibly eject from his office by two AGENTS. One Agent is CLARK NELSON.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: You have absolutely no right to invade my office, damn it.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT NELSON
dialogues.text: It's the government's office. My orders are to seal the office.  120.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT NELSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have a problem with that, take it to the Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: (to Nelson) Am I free to go?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT NELSON
dialogues.text: As far as I'm concerned, you're already gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Lawson walk with a furious Sprague.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: Guess you don't read the big city papers. The New York Times and the Washington Post ran editorials demanding that I be fired. Then Congress refused to fund the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: On what grounds?

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: The FBI demanded the right to screen my staff.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: And you said no?

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: I said hell no! I also mentioned that the FBI was a suspect in the cover-up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But you have subpoena powers.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: So I was told. But someone forgot to tell the FBI. They pause. Every passerby suddenly seems to be suspiciou

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Is it over?  121.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: Not quite. My last official act was to arrange for a key witness to testify on Monday, at the first public session.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: They can stop it or change it.

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: No, they can't -- because the witness's name has already been published.
