dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: SPRAGUE
dialogues.text: You. (Jeff reacts) Under the circumstances, I don't recommend you show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson and Jeff stroll along the site of MLK's famous demonstration.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was wrong. The times haven't changed. Hoover died, but his ghost is still here.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You didn't say it'd be easy.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: If they can kick Sprague out, if they can burn files and turn down subpoenas... the whole thing will just be a puppet show. The FBI will be investigating the FBI. (a beat) Jeff, I asked Martin to come to Memphis. I often wonder what it would be like if he were still with us. I don't want to wonder that about you...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: If the truth doesn't come out, the tragedy's just going to be repeated.  122. Lawson is moved by Jeff's transformation.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: I pray I've done the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You did the only thing. What's that part -- from Genesis you had me read? You know -- "And when they, uh, came, uh --" Lawson turns away, not wanting to recall the prophetic im of the story of Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: "And when they saw him far off, even before he came near, they conspired to slay him. And they said one to another, Behold this dreamer. Come now and let us slay him, and cast him into the pit and we will say, some evil beast has devoured him: and we shall see what will become of his dreams." Jeff looks at Lawson who gazes off at the empty steps lea to the Lincoln Monument. Light glints of the reflecting pool.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON LAWSON
dialogues.text: Deep in thought, back with Martin again.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING, (V.0)
dialogues.text: I have a dream...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: King is speaking on the steps of the Lincoln Monument.  123.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: ...that my four children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. I have a dream today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawson and Jeff are lost in thought. The cacophonous SOUN of reporters yelling questions begins to rise under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day, scores of REPORTERS are assembled up and do the steps. There are Television Crews, a number of Radio Reporters with tape recorders and a number of Print Media Reporters. They SHOUT and CACKLE as if it were a hanging.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF AND LAWSON
dialogues.text: approach the steps and begin to climb. They are surrounde by the reporters, who question them belligerently Lawson Jeff struggle up the steps without responding to the questions and taunts. Their path is blocked by the turmoi of Reporters who jostle for position, overlapping each ot

dialogues.speaker: 1ST REPORTER
dialogues.text: (to Lawson) Dr. King was your close friend. Is this just a vendetta? Do you still believe in non-violence?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND REPORTER
dialogues.text: (overlapping; to Jeff) Who's paying you? Ray pled guilty. What's there to argue? Jeff is pushed and pulled -- he shoves back. Lawson simpl absorbs the blows.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST REPORTER
dialogues.text: (to Lawson) Are you helping James Earl Ray?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD REPORTER
dialogues.text: (to Jeff) Are you gonna write a book? Why were you fired by your firm?  124.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST REPORTER
dialogues.text: Why's your father here? Is he going to testify against you? Jeff freezes. So does Lawson. Jeff slowly turns to face t mob. As he does he is staggered to see a solitary figure the top of the steps, staring down. JEFF'S P.O.V. Lucas Jenkins stands solemnly at the top of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: ON JEFF
dialogues.text: Reacting. Then he and Lawson climb up the steps. LUCAS'S P.O.V. Jeff's eyes are riveted on his father. Has he come to testify against him? Step by step, Jeff and Lawson keep climbing -- the Report parting before him -- until they stand only one step belo Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: The Special Counsel has already been dismissed. What can you possibly have to offer?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (to the Press) Address your questions to me.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: (to Lucas) Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (a long pause) I'm Mr. Jeffrey Jenkins' attorney.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don't need you to defend me.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: No defense. We're going to press for the truth.

dialogues.speaker: LAWSON
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Lucas.  125.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Good to be seen. Lawson, Jeff and Lucas make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (breaking the moment) Gentlemen -- we have some work that needs to be done. Leaving the media circus behind, Lucas, Jeff, and Reveren Lawson turn, mount the final steps, and enter the House Office Building.
